title: Anti-Money Laundering by Group-Aware Deep Graph Learning
text:
Abstract 
 Money laundering (ML) is a serious challenge that supports organized and transnational crime, with far-reaching impacts on a country’s economy, governance, and social welfare. Financial institutions, which manage the flow of money, Financial institutions have become essential partners in the global battle against money laundering. While traditional AML systems typically assess transactions one by one, they often fail to detects the large patterns that emerges when criminal groups operate in coordination. Today, money laundering is often orchestrated by organized networks rather than individuals acting alone. Recognizing this shift, a deep graph learning model now makes it possible to detect collaborative money laundering by zooming in on group dynamics and shared behaviors. Our approach models users and their transactions as interconnected nodes within a graph, using a community-based encoder to capture group dynamics and behavioral patterns. Additionally, we apply a local feature enhancement method to identify and group similar transactional behaviors, helping to uncover hidden laundering networks. This Experiments are using an actual data from a leading international bank card network revealed that this approach delivers notably higher accuracy in detecting suspicious activity. It delivers superior results compared to current anti-money laundering methods, consistently identifying suspicious activity more effectively in both live monitoring and scheduled data analysis. These findings underscore how using graph-based techniques to capture group-level patterns can make AML systems far more effective at spotting complex, coordinated financial crimes. 
 
 
 Introduction 
 1. Money Laundering Overview 
 Money laundering involves disguising illegally obtained money to make it appear legitimate. It supports organized crime and is estimated to account for about 2.7% of global GDP. Traditional anti-money laundering (AML) methods are rule-based and labor-intensive. New technologies like machine learning (ML) and deep learning are now being adopted to automate and improve detection—but they often struggle to detect coordinated laundering activities by organized groups. 
 
 2. Proposed Approach: Group-Aware Graph Neural Network (GAGNN) 
 To overcome limitations of traditional AML models, researchers propose a Group-Aware Graph Neural Network (GAGNN) that: 
 
 
 Models accounts as nodes and transactions as edges in a graph. 
 
 
 Captures both individual behavior and group dynamics. 
 
 
 Uses Graph Attention Networks (GAT) and Extended Markov Random Fields (eMRF) to identify suspicious communities. 
 
 
 Classifies suspicious activity at three levels: 
 
 
 Individual accounts 
 
 
 Transactions 
 
 
 Groups of users (super-nodes) 
 
 
 
 
 This multi-level structure enables better detection of organized money laundering schemes. It is scalable, trained offline, and suitable for real-time deployment. 
 
 3. Literature Review – Key Techniques and Contributions 
 a. Time-Frequency Analysis (El Ammari et al., 2021) 
 Uses Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) to detect laundering patterns over time. Captures dynamic, repetitive financial behavior with high accuracy. 
 b. Deep Learning Models (Ghosh et al., 2023) 
 Applies models like RNNs, LSTMs, CNNs, and GNNs for complex pattern recognition. Highlights the importance of explainable AI (XAI) tools (e.g., LIME, SHAP) to improve transparency. 
 c. Rule-Based Detection (Butgereit, 2021) 
 Uses rule-based logic (e.g., 12 Red Flags) to detect funnel accounts in mobile finance, effective where labeled data is scarce. 
 d. Visual Analytics for Crypto AML (Wang et al., 2022) 
 Introduces a visual framework using transaction flows and clustering to detect laundering in cryptocurrency exchanges—helpful for non-technical investigators. 
 e. Hybrid Model (Koo et al., 2024) 
 Combines an autoencoder for anomaly detection with a risk-based scoring system, balancing unsupervised learning with expert-driven rules. 
 f. Explainable AI via xGEMs (Dou, 2020) 
 Provides interpretable counterfactuals using generative models to explain decisions made by black-box ML models, enhancing trust in AI systems. 
 g. Graph-Based Detection with Sparse Data (Liu et al., 2020) 
 Presents a scalable Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) that learns from limited labeled data using sampling and embedding. Effective for large, sparse financial graphs. 
 
 4. Key Innovations of GAGNN 
 
 
 Graph-based transaction modeling 
 
 
 Group-level analysis for detecting coordinated crime 
 
 
 Community-aware attention and inference 
 
 
 Multi-layer classification (users, transactions, groups) 
 
 
 Scalable and real-time capable system 
 
 
 
 
 Conclusion 
 The growing complexity of financial crime demands more intelligent, adaptable, and interpretable solutions—deep graph learning offers a promising path forward in this effort. By modeling relationships between entities and capturing group behaviors within financial networks, graph-based approaches, This approach significantly surpasses the limitations of conventional anti-money laundering methods, offering deeper insights and more adaptive solutions. This survey has highlighted a range of innovative methods, from group-aware neural networks and semi-supervised frameworks to autoencoder-based anomaly detection and explainable AI tools. Each contributes uniquely to detecting both individual and collaborative money laundering patterns in real-world settings. Despite notable progress, challenges remain. Limited access to reliable data, concerns about how models make decisions, and challenges in scaling them up are still major roadblocks to broader adoption.. However, recent advancements in hybrid learning models, interpretability techniques, and scalable graph architectures suggest a promising future for research and practical deployment. Going forward, collaboration between financial institutions, regulatory bodies, and the research community will be essential to build AML systems that are not only accurate but also trustworthy and operationally viable. Ultimately, deep graph learning is not just a technical innovation—it’s a foundational shift in how we understand and combat financial crime in the digital age. 
 
 
 References 
 [1] Liu, H., Zuo, Y., Zhu, X., Yin, H., & Zhang, M. (2021). Anti-money laundering by group-aware deep graph learning. In Proceedings of the 27th ACM SIGKDD Conference on Knowledge Discovery & Data Mining (pp. 1113–1123). ACM.
[2] B. Unger, \"Money laundering regulation: From al Capone to al qaeda,\" in Research Handbook on Money Laundering Anonymous 2013, .
[3] M. El Ammari, H. Rachidi, and Y. Benslimane, \"A time-frequency based suspicious activity detection for anti-money laundering,\" in Proc. 2021 4th International Conference on Advanced Systems and Emergent Technologies (IC_ASET), Hammamet, Tunisia, 2021, pp. 177–182. doi: 10.1109/IC_ASET52486.2021.9691095.
[4] A. Ghosh, M. V. R. K. R. R. Atrey, and A. B. Benerjee, \"Deep learning and explainable artificial intelligence techniques applied for detecting money laundering: A critical review,\" Computers & Security, vol. 130, 2023, Art. no. 103138, doi: 10.1016/j.cose.2023.103138.
[5] L. Butgereit, \"Anti Money Laundering: Rule-Based Methods to Identify Funnel Accounts,\" in Proc. 2021 Conf. on Information Communications Technology and Society (ICTAS), Port Elizabeth, South Africa, 2021, pp. 20–26. doi: 10.1109/ICTAS50802.2021.9394990.
[6] Wang, H., Wang, X., Yang, D., & Wu, Y. (2022). “Visual analysis of money laundering in cryptocurrency exchange.” IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, 28(1), 98–108. 
[7] K. Koo, M. Park, and B. Yoon, \"A suspicious financial transaction detection model using autoencoder and risk-based approach,\" IEEE Access, vol. 12, pp. 68926–68939, May 2024, doi: 10.1109/ACCESS.2024.3399824.
[8] Yingtong Dou1, Zhiwei Liu1, Li Sun2, Yutong Deng2, Hao Peng3, Philip S. Yu1 ‘‘Enhancing Graph Neural Network-based Fraud Detectors against Camouflaged Fraudsters,’’. 1. IEEE, 2020.
[9] Liu, A., Tong, Y., Li, Z., Deng, K., He, X., & Tong, H. (2020). “Scalable semi-supervised graph learning techniques for anti-money laundering”. arXiv preprint arXiv:2009.05344
[10] T. N. Kipf and M. Welling, ``Semi-supervised classification with graph convolutional networks,\'\' in Proc. Int. Conf. Learn. Represent. (ICLR), 2017, pp. 114.
[11] R. Liu, X.-L. Qian, S. Mao, and S.-Z. Zhu, ``Research on anti money laundering based on core decision tree algorithm,\'\' in Proc. IEEE Chin. Control Decis. Conf. (CCDC), May 2011, pp. 4322 4325.
[12] Z. Chen, L. Dinh Van Khoa, A. Nazir, E. N. Teoh, and E. K. Karupiah ``Exploration of the effectiveness of expectation maximization algorithm for suspicious transaction detection in anti money laundering,\'\' in Proc. IEEE Conf. Open Syst. (ICOS), Oct. 2014, pp. 145 149.
[13] K. Singh and P. Best, “Anti-money laundering: Using data visualization to identify suspicious activity,” Int. J. Accounting Inf. Syst., vol. 34, no. 3, pp. 7–13, 2019.
[14] N. Heidarinia, A. Harounabadi, and M. Sadeghzadeh, “An intelligent anti-money laundering method for detecting risky users in the banking systems,” Int. J. Comput. Appl., vol. 97, no. 22, pp. 35–39, Jul. 2014.
[15] M.-J. Segovia-Vargas et al., “Money laundering and terrorism financing detection using neural networks and an abnormality indicator,” Expert Syst. Appl., vol. 169, 2021, Art. no. 11447
 
 
 
 Copyright 
 Copyright © 2025 Shwetha A B, Shreyas H G, Siddarameshwara J, Srinidhi M, Srujan T S. This is an open access article distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution License, which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

title: AI-Powered Fraud Detection in Financial Services: GNN, ...
text:
34 Pages 
 Posted: 10 Mar 2025 
 
 Date Written: March 07, 2025 
 
 Abstract 
 The rapid evolution of financial fraud, coupled with increasing regulatory scrutiny, challenges conventional fraud detection approaches. Traditional machine learning models struggle to capture complex fraud networks and evolving transactional patterns. This study proposes a Graph Neural Network (GNN)-based fraud detection framework, integrating network science, deep learning, and Explainable AI (XAI) to enhance fraud prevention in financial systems while ensuring compliance with anti-money laundering (AML) and knowyour-customer (KYC) regulations. By structuring financial transactions as graphs, GNNs identify hidden dependencies, collusive fraud, and synthetic identity fraud more effectively than traditional models. We benchmark GNNs against Random Forest and XGBoost, demonstrating superior recall and detection accuracy. Furthermore, we evaluate computational efficiency and real-time feasibility, addressing the scalability challenges of AI-driven fraud detection in highfrequency financial environments. Our findings suggest that integrating GNNs into financial information systems and fintech platforms significantly enhances fraud detection accuracy, risk assessment, and regulatory transparency. This research offers actionable insights for financial institutions, regulators, and AI practitioners, positioning graph-based AI methodologies as a critical innovation for ethical, scalable, and compliant financial crime prevention. 
 
 Keywords: Financial Fraud Detection, Graph Neural Networks, Anomaly Detection, AI Ethics, Compliance, Risk Management

title: Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Anti-Money Laundering
text:
Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Anti-Money Laundering | SAS
[SAS | The Power to Know](https://www.sas.com)
![Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Anti-Money Laundering](https://www.sas.com/en/whitepapers/explainable-artificial-intelligence-for-anti-money-laundering/_jcr_content/par/textimage/image.img.jpg/1753125027446.jpg "Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Anti-Money Laundering")
**White Paper**
# Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Anti-Money Laundering
presented by SAS
Machine learning holds considerable promise for improving anti-money laundering efforts, but adoption has been slow due in part to regulatory demands for transparency. This white paper explores how explainable AI (XAI) techniques address the “black box” nature of ML models, enabling financial institutions to meet governance standards while benefiting from AI’s strengths. With increasing regulatory support for responsible AI, this paper provides practical guidance for building transparent, compliant and effective AML systems powered by machine learning.

i
Acknowledgements
I would like to express my deepest gratitude to my supervisors, dr. Erik Jan van Leeuwen
and dr. Ioana Karnstedt-Hulpus, for their invaluable guidance throughout the course of my
master’s thesis. Their expertise, insights, and constructive feedback have been instrumental in
shaping this work. Additionally, I would like to thank prof. dr. Hans Bodlaender for reading
and judging my thesis. I am also thankful to Vahid, Ramón and Karen for our bi-weekly
group sessions and lunches, where I could share my progress, receive helpful suggestions, and
draw inspiration from their work on similar projects. I extend my gratitude to my fellow
students and good friends for the fun we have had over the past five years and to my parents
and brother for always supporting me. Lastly, I want to express my sincerest appreciation
to Lianne for her help, belief and encouragement throughout this project. You have the
best patience and always provide me with much-needed distraction during the evenings and
weekends. Thank you.
ii
Abstract
Powerful Graph Neural Networks for
Money Laundering Pattern Detection
by Stan Verlaan
This research enhances graph neural networks (GNN) for identifying suspicious accounts
involved in money laundering. Extending the work of Egressy et al. (2024), we modify and
propose a set of techniques that enable GNNs to detect suspicious subgraph patterns in the
weighted temporal networks underlying financial data. These techniques include a novel
message passing scheme, which allows for the indication of edge directionality within a single
aggregator function, element-wise edge weight multiplication, and an LSTM aggregator that
can learn from the sequential order of edges imposed by timestamps. Our LAS-GNN model
is based on an inductive learning framework and can generalize across different networks.
Experimental results on synthetic networks show that LAS-GNN is robust and can identify
basic money laundering patterns, such as smurfing motifs and simple cycles up to length
6, to near perfection, outperforming a graph isomorphism network benchmark with edge
features. While the primary focus is on the financial crime domain, the findings have broader
applications in dynamic network settings.

1
Chapter 1
Introduction
1.1 Background
Money laundering (ML) is the process of concealing the origin of illegitimately obtained money. It
involves the conversion of illicit funds into seemingly legitimate assets. This “dirty” money can be
obtained from all sorts of illegal activities, such as embezzlement, drug and human trafficking, and
the funding of terrorist organizations, and is disguised so that it can be used without the detection
of said activities. According to the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), between
2% to 5% of the global Gross Domestic Product (GDP) can be attributed to money laundering,
which amounts to 800 billion to 2 trillion US dollars. This makes the money laundering business
one of the largest industries in the world. With the growth of global economy, e-businesses and
online transactions, it is predicted that the number of money laundering crimes will continue to
increase (Zhang et al., 2003). The implications this has for both the economy and society as a
whole are significant and wide-ranging. Aimless movement of large funds can have destabilizing
effects on financial systems, and money laundering often goes hand-in-hand with tax and duty
evasion (Capgemini). Furthermore, these funds facilitate criminal and terrorist organizations,
with obvious consequences for national safety.
Given these negative effects, detecting money laundering processes is of paramount importance.
Anti-Money Laundering (AML) refers to the set of laws, regulations, and procedures designed
and aimed at detecting, preventing, and prosecuting individuals and entities involved in money
laundering. Banks monitor transactions and report suspicious activity based on a set of rules that
are predefined by domain experts. Such rules and the statistical thresholds related to different
scenarios are motivated by industry red flags (transactions to suspicious countries) and basic
statistical indicators (amounts over a certain threshold), as well as expert judgement (Rompaye).
Even though this seems like a sensible and straightforward way of translating money laundering
concerns into a working system, such rule-based approaches suffer from some drawbacks (Gao
et al., 2009). Sophisticated criminals who are familiar with the rules can easily deceive the system
and evade detection. In turn, these rule-based systems need to be updated constantly to keep up
with the ever-evolving money laundering strategies. Furthermore, static rules may not always
be able to capture the complex patterns of money laundering trails. While the scope of a single
assessment can be broadened to include numerous transactions, this may result in much more
intricate rules that are prone to implementation errors and whose effectiveness are hard to discern.
A valuable method used by transaction offices and advocated to banks by De Nederlandse
Bank (DNB) for detecting money laundering processes is the five-step process scheme of topologies
(De Nederlandse Bank). This method analyzes historical data of transactions and clients based
on established money laundering topologies to identify accounts whose activities are similar to
the accounts in such topologies. The newly detected accounts may reveal to be part of novel
money laundering topologies, which in turn can be employed to analyze new historical data.
However, when rule-based approaches are used for matching targets and analyzing the results,
the same drawbacks still apply. Moreover, they are often associated with the generation of a
Chapter 1. Introduction 2
large number of false-positives (Gao et al., 2009) and the manual follow-up of the alerts can be a
time-consuming and labour-intensive process.
To aid in this process, more and more institutions consider the use of machine learning. With
machine learning, advanced algorithms can be utilized to identify suspicious money laundering
cases directly from the data. While this can be much more efficient, it also turns out to be more
precise and effective in practice: KPMG Belgium’s experience at a leading bank showed that
their identification of suspicious activity can be improved by up to 40% by replacing rule-based
and scenario-based tools with machine learning models (Rompaye). Apart from the increase in
performance, changing to AI-based solutions can help overcome some limitations of traditional
systems, since they are suitable for adapting to new money laundering schemes and can meet the
demand of the high volume of transactions performed on a daily basis.
In literature, a range of different machine learning models are proposed and their potential
for the domain of financial crime is investigated. These comprise anomaly detection algorithms
and traditional supervised learning approaches that can handle the severe data imbalance related
to such tasks. Recently, more sophisticated deep learning techniques that utilize the underlying
network structure of transaction data have emerged. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) that operate
on graph-structured data can be deployed for classifying accounts suspected of money laundering.
Nevertheless, research into the capabilities of such models for AML is still in its early stages
and often focus on extensive features while ignoring the structural pattern detection capabilities
necessary in the following task: Given one or more graph(s) and multiple examples of one or
more suspicious subgraph pattern(s), detect unseen nodes that occur in such pattern(s). While
a GNN can be extended to enable pattern finding of suspicious motifs, weighted and temporal
properties are often not explicitly incorporated. As a result, the dynamics of the network are not
captured by the model.
1.2 Our Contributions
In this research, we build upon the work of Egressy et al. (2024) by enhancing and proposing
techniques for graph neural networks to leverage the underlying network structure of transaction
data for detecting suspicious accounts indicative of money laundering. Instead of directly
extracting suspicious subgraph patterns from the network, the model performs supervised node
classification to identify accounts that show structural resemblance to nodes in a target pattern.
In addition to utilizing ego IDs, binary node features designed to detect cycles, we propose
a novel message passing scheme termed signed message passing, an alternative to existing
heterogeneous schemes. While heterogeneous message passing aggregates messages from incoming
and outgoing neighbours separately, signed message passing allows for the aggregation of both
types of edges simultaneously while still preserving an indication of the directionality of edges.
Furthermore, we extend the money laundering patterns (ML patterns) to the context of
weighted temporal networks by introducing the concepts of weighted patterns and temporal
patterns. By incorporating edge weight multiplication with signed message passing, our model
can detect patterns whose edge weights exceed a certain threshold. To identify temporally ordered
patterns, we propose an LSTM aggregator that learns from the sequential order of edges imposed
by timestamps. This LSTM aggregator is seamlessly integrated into the GNN layers, providing
a straightforward and intuitive method of capturing the dynamic characteristics of financial
networks.
The developed model, named LAS-GNN, is based on an embedding generation framework
that can be used in an inductive setting, allowing for generalization across distinct networks.
We test our algorithm on synthetic networks generated by ourselves and compare its detection
performance against different baselines, including a graph isomorphism network benchmark that
incorporates weights and timestamps as edge features. Although our findings can be generalized
Chapter 1. Introduction 3
and applied to other pattern detection tasks in dynamic network settings, such as molecule
detection and traffic forecasting, our focus remains on the financial crime domain of money
laundering.
This thesis is structured as follows. We begin with an overview of the related literature
regarding approaches for money laundering detection in Chapter 2. Scientific findings on standard
machine learning algorithms and advanced techniques for incorporating network structure are
discussed within the domain of AML. A more in-depth description of graph neural networks
can be found in Chapter 3, where we also describe current techniques that extend GNNs for
pattern finding. In Chapter 4, we introduce our proposed techniques and modifications to existing
methods, offering a full description of our model. This is followed by Chapter 5, which details
our experimental setup, including the generation of synthetic networks, training specifications,
compared models, and relevant evaluation metrics. The results of our model on the designed
tasks are presented in Chapter 6, where we also compare its performance to a graph isomorphism
network and other baselines. The discussion and conclusion of our research can be found in
Chapter 7 and Chapter 8, respectively.
4
Chapter 2
The State of Money Laundering
Detection
In this chapter, we discuss recent scientific developments in Money Laundering Detection (MLD).
There is a wide variety of models, which range from domain-led to entirely data-driven. The
papers discussed here consist of standard, frequently used approaches as well as state-of-the-art
models that together make up an overview of both effective and widely-used approaches for MLD.
We refer to more extensive surveys for more information (Labib et al.; Chen et al., 2018).
A problem related to money laundering detection is fraud detection, which shares many
similarities but differs in modus operandi and patterns identified. While our main focus lies on
money laundering detection specifically, we come across some results for fraud detection in the
discussed literature. Two surveys on fraud detection specifically can be found here: (Adewumi
and Akinyelu, 2017; Ali et al., 2022).
Our overview of detection approaches for money laundering begins in Section 2.1 with more
traditional supervised machine learning and anomaly detection algorithms that directly operate
on transaction data. Subsequently, we discuss graph-based approaches that explicitly utilize the
graph structure of a financial network in Section 2.2.
2.1 Transaction-Based Machine Learning for AML
In Chapter 1, we discussed the downsides of the conventional rule- and scenario-based systems that
are still primarily used at financial institutions today. Over the past decade, extensive research
has been conducted on automated AI-based solutions aimed at money laundering detection,
with more and more institutions embracing such methods alongside their traditional systems.
These machine learning methods work on data and can be broadly categorized into two types:
supervised and unsupervised. Although the former uses labelled data providing information
about alerted cases, the latter discovers hidden patterns solely from unlabeled data. Both
methods can be applied to transaction data, customer account data, or a combination of both.
While the actual information available may vary across data sets or institutions, examples of
features in transaction data consists of a transaction volume, date and time, currency, payment
type, etc. Account data may comprise the type of account (person, corporate), affiliated bank,
demographic information, and more. Note that the account features can be integrated into
transaction features by creating corresponding feature columns for the source and target account
of a transaction separately. Conversely, transaction features related to the same account can
be combined (averaged, summed, etc.) to form account features, although such operations may
affect the expressiveness of the original transaction feature values. Therefore, most studies focus
on approaches analyzing transaction data.
A problem with transaction data is that the proportion of transactions related to financial
crime is exceedingly small. While great for society, this can provide a challenge for learning
algorithms. This phenomenon, where instances of a certain class are significantly underrepresented
in the dataset, is referred to as class imbalance. Especially in domains such as financial crime,
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 5
where detecting the minority class is most crucial, it is important to take this into account
when constructing and evaluating a machine learning model. When assessing a machine learning
model using ground truth, certain performance measures, such as accuracy, can be misleading. A
classifier that only predicts the majority class is bound to yield high accuracy, although such a
model is essentially useless for MLD. Therefore, we mostly concern ourselves with the precision
and recall scores. In our discussion of related literature, we focus on aspects such as the number
of false positives, false negatives, etc. These metrics are explained in Section 5.4.
2.1.1 Supervised Learning
In the case that labelled data of actual reported money laundering cases is available, it seems
beneficial to leverage this information for creating a baseline understanding for the machine
learning model.
In an empirical study conducted by Zhang and Trubey (2019), five prominent supervised
machine learning algorithms are compared on the binary classification task of whether a transaction
qualifies as a money laundering event or not. The authors used real-world transaction data
provided by a non-disclosed U.S. financial institution. All transactions were initially alerted
as suspicious, but less than one per cent was ultimately flagged as SAR. The objective was to
distinguish the escalated alerts that were reported to the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network
(FinCEN) from the inconsequential alerts. To handle the class imbalance, the authors also applied
two sampling schemes to increase the relative presence of these events. These sampling schemes
involved over-sampling the minority class (escalated alerts) and under-sampling the majority
class (insignificant alerts). The implemented algorithms include Bayes logistic regression (BLR),
decision tree (DT), random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and artificial neural
network (ANN). These models were built using ten non-disclosed explanatory variables from a
set of roughly a hundred variables based on rich information from the transactions and customer
characteristics, including risk rate, age and location.
Results revealed that without sampling, the ANN performed best with an Area Under the
ROC Curve (AUC) of 0.74, while the SVM was the worst with an AUC of 0.60. However, while
the ANN model showed resilience against the sampling schemes, the SVM became the second-best
classifier in the case of under-sampling and even surpassed ANN as the best-performing model in
the case of severe over-sampling. The finding that SVM performs well on more balanced data sets
but not on the original, skewed data is reiterated by Alarab et al. (2020). The decision tree model
gained from both sampling schemes but was consistently ranked as the worst performing classifier
for each event rate, apart from the scenario without any sampling. Despite its lower predictive
performance, decision trees can be valuable for identifying new rules that can conveniently be
integrated into traditional rule-based systems, something done by Wang and Yang (2007) based
on customer profiles of a Chinese bank. The random forest showed strong performance both with
and without sampling.
Alarab et al. (2020) combined different supervised classification models, including RF, Extra
Trees and Bagging classifier, into an ensemble model that outperformed each individual model
in detecting illicit transactions in the Elliptic dataset, a dataset comprising real-world bitcoin
transactions. This is accomplished by simply averaging the classification probabilities obtained
by these methods. The ensemble method proved to reduce the number of false positives without
increasing the false negatives. The authors also noted that one particular model, k-Nearest
Neighbors (kNN), did not perform well and appears unsuitable for the task of money laundering
detection. kNN relies on the k closest neighbours in the feature space to vote for the best class.
However, due to the imbalanced dataset, the voting mechanism is highly likely to be skewed
towards the majority class since the numerous negative instances (licit transactions) can easily
outweigh the small number of positive instances (illicit transactions) in the neighbourhood of
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 6
a suspicious transaction. Furthermore, given that kNN is based on Euclidean distances, it is
computationally expensive, especially in the case of high-dimensional data.
At last, we also want to mention the work of Jullum et al. (2020), whose supervised XGBoost
model was trained on three types of historical data from Norway’s largest bank: 1) normal, legal
transactions, 2) transactions flagged as suspicious by the bank’s internal alert system, and 3)
potential money laundering cases reported to the authorities. Their work demonstrates that the
common approach of not using normal or non-reported transactions in the training of a model can
lead to sub-optimal results. Using a newly proposed performance measure specifically tailored for
comparing their method with the bank’s existing AML system, they show that their supervised
model can outperform the traditional rule-based systems many banks rely on.
2.1.2 Unsupervised Learning
While labelled data can be of great value for the learning algorithm, it may not always be
available. Certain financial institutions may lack access to labelled data sets due to privacy
concerns, and manually preparing and labelling large data sets can be an expensive and timeconsuming endeavour. Additionally, the labelled data may not truly match with the ground truth
in the first place since 1) it is hard to know whether some alert is actually involved in money
laundering and not just suspicious, and 2) a high percentage of money laundering cases are missed
even by experts. Hence, it is unsurprising that extensive research in money laundering detection
is concerned with unsupervised learning, where the machine learning techniques rely on a model
without prior knowledge of the data or human supervision. The objective of such methods is to
identify hidden structures and patterns as well as (dis)similarities among the data records.
The task of discovering rare occurrences in data is commonly known as anomaly detection.
In the context of money laundering, this involves identifying unusual transactions or accounts
whose behaviour deviates from that of typical accounts. A popular machine learning method
employed for outlier detection is the isolation forest. Similar to a random forest, it consists of
an ensemble of decision trees. However, rather than splitting nodes based on information gain
derived from class labels, the trees in the isolation forest randomly split data points along a
feature dimension and thus do not rely on any supervision. Isolation forests are successfully used
as the main module for illicit transaction detection by Shokry et al. (2020) and as a subroutine
within a broader detection framework by Labanca et al. (2022) and Dumitrescu et al. (2022). The
linear time complexity and low memory usage renders them highly suitable for large datasets.
An alternative approach for outlier detection is the One-Class Support Vector Machine (OCSVM). In contrast to the traditional SVM algorithm that separates the data into several classes,
the OC-SVM model is an extension made by Schölkopf et al. (2001) that only considers a single
"normal" class. To detect outliers, OC-SVM creates a boundary around the normal observations
to isolate them from the anomalous ones. While Alarab et al. (2020) showed that traditional
SVM performs poorly when the transaction data is highly imbalanced, it is precisely under these
circumstances that OC-SVM shows great promise. Tang and Yin (2005) modified the OC-SVM
algorithm for AML using a transaction database from an agriculture bank in China. The authors
conclude that their method is simple and rapid and can be used in real-world systems without
much modification. However, they acknowledge that the model parameters were determined
through trial and error and could be tuned differently for better performance. In the absence of
labelled data, model validation and evaluation can be challenging for unsupervised models.
Contrary to previous research, Lorenz (2021) suggest that unsupervised methods solely relying
on anomaly detection are ineffective for real-life AML. They note that in some past experiments,
data is synthetically generated to contain outliers by design, something that does not materialize in
real-world data. By applying Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) (McInnes
et al., 2018) on Bitcoin transaction data to visualize the classifications of an isolation forest and
the ground truth, the authors show that the illicit transactions in a real-life Bitcoin transaction
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 7
network are not outlying at all. The observation that not all outliers are illicit and not all illicit
transactions are outliers is reasonable in AML, as sophisticated criminals generally attempt to
mimic normal behaviour. This problem was previously acknowledged by Das et al. (2016) and is
said to be a root cause for the high false positive and high false negative rates frequently associated
with these methods. In both studies, the authors overcome this by applying anomaly detection
algorithms in a broader active learning framework in which expert feedback is incorporated to
adjust the detector during an interactive loop. These iterative "analyst-in-the-loop" approaches
can be classified as semi-supervised since they learn patterns from mostly unlabelled data using
small inputs from human supervision.
2.2 Graph-based Approaches for AML
The methods discussed in Section 2.1 learn directly from the observations specified in the data and
do not explicitly leverage the financial network. In this section, we discuss models and approaches
that do work with the relations specified by the underlying graph structure. After constructing a
financial graph, with bank accounts and transactions represented by nodes and edges, respectively,
as illustrated in Figure 2.1, one could apply one of many graph-based approaches. These models
can be domain-led or data-driven, and they may explicitly search for suspicious money laundering
subgraph patterns or not. In this section, we first discuss some domain-led approaches. Then, we
proceed with graph-based machine learning models and discuss three promising techniques as
seen in literature: directly using features derived from the network, generating graph embeddings
using random walks, and utilizing more advanced deep learning methods. The latter will be the
main focus of our research.

2.2.1 Domain-led
While the primary focus of this thesis is on learning algorithms, we want to mention some notable
algorithms for MLD that do not exactly learn in a data-driven manner but use the graph data in
a direct and algorithmic way. These approaches are more domain-led and depend on similarity
measures, database processing, and threshold modelling.
Li et al. (2020) note a shortcoming of several general-purpose anomaly detection techniques,
such as Fraudar (Hooi et al., 2016), D-Cube (Shin et al., 2017), and HoloScope (Liu et al.,
2018), that have been developed for discovering structural anomalies in financial graphs. These
approaches do not focus on money flow across multiple nodes, which is essential for ensuring
accuracy and resilience against camouflage in ML activities. Instead, the authors propose a novel
anomalousness metric that captures two money laundering specific traits, namely that 1) transfers
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 8
are dense due to high volume funds that flow between few nodes, and 2) intermediate accounts
serve as a bridge and therefore often have a zero-out balance between their weighted in-degree
and out-degree. Their proposed FlowScope algorithm extracts the densest tripartite subgraph
from the network according to this metric in near-linear time using a priority tree. In order to
find more suspicious groups of nodes, the densest subgraph is removed from the network, and the
algorithm gets rerun. FlowScope is primarily tested on tripartite subgraphs with a single middle
layer, although it also outperforms the previously mentioned algorithms in scenarios involving
two layers of intermediate nodes.
Starnini et al. (2021) focus on identifying two specific smurf-like motifs in time-evolving
transaction networks, namely the gather-scatter and scatter-gather patterns. They detect such
patterns rapidly, using standard database joins that find common neighbours between different
pairs of nodes within the same time window. However, their approach is predominantly reliant on
a series of pre-processing and post-processing steps. Initially, trustworthy accounts or accounts
with activity above a certain threshold are removed, as well as transactions involving a low
amount of money. Furthermore, they ensure that each path of length two includes at least one
cross-border transaction. They use a specific threshold for the maximum inter-transaction time
window, along with constraints for the minimum total money flow and flow ratio for filtering the
suspicious subgraphs in post-processing. The authors extract some notable patterns, visualized
using flowcharts. Since this approach relies heavily on rules and thresholds, they intentionally
leave the values non-disclosed.
Similar thresholds are also used in the research of Soltani et al. (2016). They incorporate the
temporal and amount similarity between two transactions using a single equation, which is used
to match transactions where the receiver account of one transaction corresponds to the sender
account of the other. The authors subsequently construct a new graph exclusively containing these
matching transactions and proceed to filter the nodes based on a designated balance score. Nodes
with a balance score exceeding a certain threshold are considered potential money laundering
accounts and are subjected to further analysis using a structural similarity metric. Finally, groups
of money launderers are found by an algorithm that iteratively merges nodes that have at least
one common neighbour. Experiments conducted on synthetically generated data show that their
framework can effectively find scatter-gather patterns without specifically injecting this type of
pattern.
The modelling of relationships in constructed graphs has been extensively researched in Social
Network Analysis, and insight from this domain can also be applied in the context of money
laundering detection. Dreżewski et al. (2015) construct social networks from bank statements and
the National Court Register and assign roles to nodes based on node centralities such as closeness
and betweenness, page rank, authoritativeness, and other measures. The purpose of these metrics
is to determine the associations between accounts and the strength of their connections depending
on their financial actions. The authors manage to point out leaders and vulnerabilities in the
network, paving the way for more in-depth investigations into their connections. A similar
approach is undertaken by Colladon and Remondi (2017) and they advocate for combining the
centrality measures with machine learning approaches for detecting suspicious accounts.
2.2.2 Graph-based Features
Note that the domain-led approaches discussed in the previous section do not learn from the
data and are hence limited to the static implementation of the algorithms. Consequently, they
cannot adapt to new complex money laundering patterns and rich feature information cannot be
incorporated. To overcome this, we now return to the machine learning algorithms described in
Section 2.1. However, instead of directly fitting some classification model to the transaction data,
there has been a lot of interest recently for incorporating the network structure in these learning
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 9
algorithms. While the research on graph-based machine learning models for MLD is increasing, it
has only been prominent in the last three years (Bakhshinejad, 2023).
The most obvious way to incorporate graph structure into a machine learning model is by
extending it with features derived from the network. The benefit of specifically designed features
is that they can be based on insights into money laundering motifs and help the machine learning
algorithm’s findings become more easily accepted by banking experts. Note that they can help
increase the performance of both supervised and unsupervised models. Straightforward examples
of such features are the incoming- and outgoing degree of a node and node centrality measures,
such as the ones mentioned in Section 2.2.1.
Dumitrescu et al. (2022) expand upon previous research on egonet features for fraud detection,
as initially explored by Akoglu et al. (2010). The egonet of a specific center node v is the induced
subgraph of v and all its immediate neighbours, including the ties among the neighbours. The
authors propose a similar subgraph, termed the reduced egonet, where the nodes connected to
v with only a single edge are removed. It turns out that some features of the reduced egonet
are biased towards the extreme for certain nodes in ML patterns compared to normal nodes.
Metrics such as the (relative) out-degree of the reduced egonet are clearly informative for anomaly
detection and can be used as indicators for money laundering. Additionally, the authors compute
random walks on the input graph to extract information on the amount of money circulated over
long paths, especially in the case of cycles. For each node k, they generate random walks with
given maximum length r, starting or ending in k, and they keep track of the minimum amount
transferred along the random walk. The assumption the authors make is that in the usual case
there is little correlation between the transactions of the nodes along the random walk, and so
this amount is expected to be small. When the amount is large, it may signify money deliberately
circulated through many accounts in an attempt to cover their origin. The maximum of this
minimum value over all random walks of a node k of length at most r is used together with the
features derived from the reduced egonet as the inputs for an isolation forest to detect accounts in
ML patterns such as fan-in and gather-scatter. Apart from using random walks to calculate direct
features, they can also be utilized for generating node embeddings, discussed in Section 2.2.3.
The streaming model proposed by Sun et al. (2022) introduces the MonLAD algorithm, which
sequentially processes edges based on their corresponding transaction timestamps. At each step,
statistical features of the nodes affected by that transaction are updated. By keeping track of the
account residual and balance scores (relating to the amount of money residing in the account),
the authors model a key trait of typical money laundering accounts, namely frequently balancing:
accounts crave to frequently reach a balanced state by fan-outs upon receiving all the money of
multiple fan-ins. The additional traits of fast-in and fast-out and high throughput are modelled by
analyzing the frequency of balancing and the magnitude of imbalances observed. The concepts of
balancing statistics are similar to the proposed FlowScope (Li et al., 2020) and structural similarity
(Soltani et al., 2016) models discussed in Section 2.2.1 and thus the MonLAD algorithm can be
considered domain-led. However, in contrary to those algorithms, the authors use these statistics
as input features for their proposed anomaly detection algorithm AnoScore, that identifies outliers
based on statistical deviation from a generalized Pareto distribution. Experiments show that
MonLAD surpasses baselines such as FlowScope in detecting injected ML anomalies while also
scaling linearly with the number of edges of the stream.
An alternative method to incorporate the network into a set of features is by first extracting
small communities of related accounts centred around a single node. Subsequently, existing
features, such as demographic and transaction features, of the parties within a specific community
are aggregated to form community-broad features. This approach is adopted by Savage et al.
(2016), and the resulting community features, along with dynamic features derived from time-series
analysis (burst analysis providing an indication of transaction regularity), serve as input for
supervised learning using SVM and random forest.
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 10
2.2.3 Random Walk Embeddings
While graph-based features for a node can be computed directly from the network, an alternative
approach is to learn node representations. Node representations, also referred to as node
embeddings, are low-dimensional vector representations of nodes that capture the structural
and relational information such that it preserves the graph’s topology. A classical example of
a node representation learning algorithm is DeepWalk (Perozzi et al., 2014), whose generated
embeddings are used as input for downstream machine learning tasks for AML by Wagner (2019).
Based on techniques from the field of Natural Language Processing, DeepWalk performs a series
of uniform random walks in the input graph. Such a random walk is treated as a "sentence",
where the visited nodes are the "words". Truncated random walks are fed into the SkipGram
algorithm that learns the probability distribution of the co-occurrence of nodes, from which the
node representations can be derived.
The Node2Vec algorithm (Grover and Leskovec, 2016) improves upon DeepWalk by introducing
the concept of biased random walks, where the walks are guided by two parameters that control
the level of local (BFS) and global (DFS) exploration. In the work of Yuan et al. (2020), both
DeepWalk and Node2Vec embeddings are fed into an OC-SVM and compared in the context of
fraud detection in Ethereum transaction networks. Their results in detecting phishing scams
show that the model using the node representations learned by Node2Vec yields better precision
and recall. The effectiveness of Node2Vec is also investigated specifically for money laundering
detection by Bakhshinejad (2023). Using 100.000 transaction records of the synthetic PAYSIM
dataset (Lopez-Rojas et al., 2016), the authors carry out cross-validation experiments. They
systematically vary parameters such as the size of the embedding vectors, the number of walks,
and walk length to determine their impact on performance. Their findings indicate that increasing
the size of the embedding vectors improves performance initially, although beyond a certain value,
it does not significantly affect accuracy and may even reduce results marginally. Nevertheless,
increasing the number of random walks and the length of the walks can shrink the false positive
and false negative rates, as can be expected. However, it is important to keep in mind that
increasing these parameters comes at the cost of significantly longer running times. Consequently,
concerns arise regarding the feasibility of this approach on much larger networks, prompting a
trade-off between computational resources and detection accuracy.
2.2.4 Deep Learning
The random walk embedding methods described in the previous section are based on the idea that
nodes that are close in the graph have similar representations. While there are alternatives to
purely proximity-based random walk embedding methods, such as the structural-based Struc2Vec
(Ribeiro et al., 2017), these methods do not take any actual properties of the nodes into account.
In other words, rich feature information from account or transaction data is completely ignored
when the classification model solely relies on the embeddings generated by Node2Vec, for instance.
Naturally, one can include these other features alongside the embeddings to form a larger feature
set before applying any machine learning algorithm. However, it seems more beneficial to let the
embeddings be guided by the features in the first place.
Fortunately, such methods exist. Graph Neural Networks (GNN) can learn node and graph
embeddings by taking both the graph structure and the node features as input. It works by
propagating information along the edges of the graph to update the node representations. This
message passing, in combination with multiple layers and non-linear activation functions, can
capture relationships and complex patterns in the data. In the last few years, GNNs have gained
extreme popularity and different types of architecture variations are proposed and applied in
many domains, including money laundering detection. The most widely used GNN model is the
Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) introduced by Kipf and Welling (2017), described in more
detail in Chapter 3.
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 11
The potential of GNNs for anti-money laundering was first demonstrated by Weber et al.
(2018). The authors argue in favour of more advanced forensic analysis tools and state that
deep learning for massive, dynamic graph data is more promising than the use of suspiciousness
heuristics and must be considered an essential addition to current graph analytic approaches.
They perform preliminary testing of graph neural networks applied to a large financial network
(1M nodes, 9M edges), which is synthetically generated and injected with the basic ML patterns
using the AMLSim data simulator (Suzumura and Kanezashi, 2021). Unfortunately, they do
not provide classification results but solely report on the running times and scalability of GCN
and FastGCN, which uses layer-wise sampling for efficiency. They are confident that with the
development of high-performance code and memory-efficient graph representations, GNNs are
well suited for handling dynamic transaction data at great scale.
In recent follow-up research, Egressy et al. (2024) apply all kinds of GNN variations to
synthetic data generated by their updated data simulator AMLWorld (Altman et al., 2024). The
models include additional techniques for the Graph Isomorphism Network, which is theoretically
found to be the most powerful GNN (Xu et al., 2019), and the Graph Attention Network,
which leverages attention mechanisms. The models and their modifications show great results in
detecting the key ML patterns on both synthetic AML data and real-world Ethereum phishing
data. The techniques of ego IDs (marking a center node with a distinct binary feature), portnumbering (for distinguishing multi-edges), and heterogeneous message passing (for indicating
edge directionality), seem to broaden the expressiveness of the GNN architecture. While these
techniques were proposed in earlier work of others separately, the authors prove both theoretically
and experimentally that it is the combination of the three that enables the detection of ML
patterns in directed multi-graphs. These techniques are described in more detail in Chapter 3.
The mentioned models were all applied to large static graphs that contained all the transactions
within a certain period. A common approach here is to use a sliding time-window to divide
the network into subgraphs containing the edges whose timestamp are within a certain interval.
Weber et al. (2019) experimented with integrating the temporal aspects of the data into the GNN
and proposed EvolveGCN: a model that consists of multiple GCNs, namely one for each time-step,
which are fed into a Recurrent Neural Network to capture the system dynamics. This way, the
weights of the GCN in a future time-step are updated based on those from the past so that it
captures the evolution of money laundering patterns. However, the model is highly complicated
and has high computational complexity, making it unsuitable for large networks. Moreover,
experiments with the Elliptic Dataset, using the 49 snap-shots in the dataset as time-steps, show
that the improvement of EvolveGCN over standard GCN was not substantial at all. Xia et al.
(2022) and Alarab and Prakoonwit (2023) also consider the combination of GCN with a recurrent
neural network, namely Long Short Term Memory (LSTM). They propose using a GCN to explore
spatial structure features in a financial network and then transferring the mined features to an
LSTM for temporal feature extraction. Although temporal features can be integrated in this way,
the network dynamics are not captured.
Wan and Li (2024) also note that existing literature is limited to representing node relationships
in static graphs. Additionally, they state that performing graph convolutional operations for
multiple time steps can cause information leakage issues and excessive smoothing. To address
this, they propose the construction of dynamic graph snapshots with symmetrical spatiotemporal
structures based on transaction information. In these graph snapshots, each transaction is treated
as a node and currency flows are regarded as edge relationships. At all times, only one graph
snapshot is retained, whose representation is updated after the transaction set of the current
time step is processed, achieving dynamic, iterative updates for the model. At each time step,
message passing in the graph snapshot is performed to extract spatial structural features, and
the results are subsequently fed into an LSTM network to further extract the temporal features.
The novelty lies in their approach to dynamic graph convolution, which combines the embedding
values from the current graph convolution layer of the previous time step and the embedding
Chapter 2. The State of Money Laundering Detection 12
output from the previous layer at the current time step. Both embeddings are concatenated and
fed into a multilayer perceptron (MLP) to update the node states at the current time step.
At last, we want to mention two other notable studies that utilize GNNs in their AML
approach. Instead of using GNNs directly for classifying suspicious accounts or transactions,
these methods perform anomaly detection in a more adversarial manner. Li et al. (2023) propose
Diga, a guided diffusion model. Their semi-supervised model first employs a subgraph sampler,
which extracts the most informative neighbours of each account based on biased PageRank and
constructs a subgraph surrounding it. Secondly, these subgraphs are treated as independent
training samples and are fed into a guided diffusion model. This diffusion model attempts to
recover the input subgraph to an anomaly-free version. It first injects noise into the subgraph
and subsequently applies GNN layers that try to reconstruct the original graph in a denoising
process. Eventually, the reconstruction error is used as the anomaly score of each account.
The algorithm LaundroGraph by Cardoso et al. (2022) is completely self-supervised and thus
does not use labelled data. Instead, it jointly trains an encoder and decoder that consist of
multiple graph convolutional layers by sampling positive instances, which are directed edges in the
graph, and non-edges as negative instances. Here, the existing edges are edges from an account
node to a transaction node in a bipartite graph. For each instance, the K-hop subgraph also
serves as input. The GNN is trained using a binary cross entropy loss function in a link prediction
task between account-transaction pairs, which essentially corresponds to an anomaly detection
task. The model learns the transaction behaviour of accounts, which serves as a reference point
of expected behaviour used to score the anomalousness of new transactions entering the system.
The novelty of this approach comes from the alternative graph representation used and the focus
on applying the method to score newly incoming transactions, which is overlooked by most GNN
approaches that classify nodes already present in the network.
13
Chapter 3
Graph Neural Networks
Although the Graph Neural Network (GNN) model was first proposed in 2005 by Gori et al. (2005)
and subsequently generalized in 2008 by Scarselli et al. (2008), its application has only gained
wide attention in recent years. In this chapter, we discuss two different settings for learning on
graphs: transductive and inductive learning. We first discuss the most prominent example of the
former and arguably the most influential GNN, the Graph Convolutional Network, in Section 3.2.
Then, we focus on a general inductive framework that seems more appropriate for our problem
and describe the popular GraphSAGE and Graph Isomorphism Network models in Section 3.3.
Finally, in Section 3.4, we discuss specific techniques that extend these inductive GNN models for
pattern detection. For a more complete survey of GNN architectures, challenges, and applications,
we refer to Khemani et al. (2024).
3.1 Transductive vs. Inductive
While graph neural networks are end-to-end frameworks useful in a variety of tasks, such as node
classification and link prediction, they are essentially tools for generating embeddings similar
to the random walk methods discussed in Section 2.2.3. Such approaches often require that all
nodes in the graph are present during training, meaning that they are inherently transductive.
When training the model for node classification for instance, all information is used with the
exception of the labels of the nodes in the test set. Consequently, transductive methods can only
generate embeddings for a single fixed graph and they cannot learn to generalize across different
graphs (Song et al., 2022). These methods are often useful in tasks where the network exhibits a
certain degree of homophily, meaning that similar nodes are more likely to connect than dissimilar
nodes. Consequently, nodes of the same type tend to cluster together, a phenomenon commonly
observed in social network analysis (McPherson et al., 2001).
However, transductive learning seems less appropriate in evolving or dynamic graphs, since
these methods are not able to efficiently generalize to unseen nodes; as soon as a new node is added,
it is necessary to retrain the model. In these cases, an inductive framework seems better suited,
where the model leverages node feature information to efficiently generate node embeddings for
previously unseen data. We argue that for money laundering detection specifically this is more
appropriate, since new transactions are made constantly and bank accounts can be opened and
closed. Furthermore, it can be the case that labeled data (known money laundering cases) that
we want to leverage comes from a different period or dataset than the data we want to make
predictions on. Moreover, in our endeavour to identify money laundering patterns, we assume
the network exhibits a certain degree of heterophily. Although suspicious nodes are connected to
other suspicious nodes within the same ML pattern, such patterns tend to be relatively small.
When we consider the suspicious nodes from distinct patterns, there is no assumption on how
closely they are located in the graph. In other words, the ML patterns we seek can be distributed
across the entire network and we must learn to recognize the structural properties of a node’s
neighbourhood that generalize between patterns. The inductive setting seems better suited to
this notion of heterophily. Both settings are illustrated in Figure 3.1.

3.2 Graph Convolutional Network
The Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) is an inherently transductive method. Similar to
most GNN variations that came after, GCN aims to generalize well-established neural models
like Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to work on
arbitrarily structured graphs. They all share a somewhat general architecture where the objective
is to learn a function on a graph G = (V, E) which takes as input
• the adjacency matrix A, which describes the graph structure of G,
• an N × D feature matrix X, which summarizes a feature description xv for each node v ∈ V
(N is the number of nodes, D the number of input features per node),
and produces a node-level output Z, which is an N × F matrix with F the number of output
features per node. We can then write every neural network layer as a non-linear function f as
follows. For any k ≥ 1
H(k) = f(H(k−1), A), (3.1)
with H(0) = X and H(K) = Z, where K is the total number of layers. The specific models then
vary solely based on how f(·, ·) is chosen and parameterized.
A simplistic layer-wise propagation rule is
H(k) = f(H(k−1), A) = σ(AH(k−1)W(k)). (3.2)
Here W(k)is the weight matrix for layer k, and σ(·) is a non-linear activation function like ReLU.
Although this propagation rule can already be quite powerful on its own, there are two limitations
that need to be fixed.
First, in case there are no self-loops in the graph, the multiplication of A sums up all the
feature vectors of the neighbouring nodes for each node, but excludes the node itself. A simple
fix is to add the identity matrix I to A such that self-loops are enforced.
Chapter 3. Graph Neural Networks 15
Secondly, A must be normalized such that all rows sum to one. Otherwise, the scale of the
feature values will completely change after the multiplication. Normalization is often achieved by
an additional multiplication with the inverse of the diagonal node degree matrix D. Multiplying
with D−1A in the layer propagation rule now amounts to averaging neighbouring node features.
Symmetric normalization, i.e. D− 1

results.

GCN model:

In the training phase, the weights in the weight matrices W(1), . . . , W(K) are learned using a
loss function. After forward propagation through the network, a sigmoid function is applied to
the last layer, which yields the current predicted probability outcomes for the node class labels in
case of node classification. For supervised learning, the cross entropy loss is then computed using
the actual known class labels. For binary classification, this binary cross entropy loss function is
as follows:

in each layer are updated using stochastic gradient descent.
GCN is considered a spectral GNN. In technical terms, the feature vectors of nodes are
considered multi-channel graph signals, for which the model learns spectral filters in the Fourier
domain defined by the eigenvectors of the graphs Laplacian matrix. This means that the filters
learned are graph specific, which explains why GCN is transductive (Mishra et al., 2020).
3.3 Inductive Representation Learning
Spatial GNNs define the convolution operation directly on the structure of the graph. Instead of
learning individual embeddings for each node in the graph, a spatial GNN learns a function that
generates embeddings for unseen nodes by aggregating features from a node’s surrounding neighbourhood. This way, it simultaneously learns the topological structure of such a neighbourhood
as well as the distribution of the features of the nodes in it.
A powerful, spatial graph neural network framework that uses node feature information
to inductively generate representations for unseen data is proposed by Hamilton et al. (2017).

adjust the weight matrices and parameters of the aggregator and update functions corresponding
to each layer k, using stochastic gradient descent. This results in an end-to-end inductive
algorithm suitable for node classification based on the learned node embeddings. An additional
advantage of this inductive framework is its efficiency in terms of both memory and time. By
conducting mini-batch training, we only consider the embedding generation for a small group of
seed nodes (i.e. a batch) at a time, avoiding the need to process an entire, potentially massive,
network at once—something that can become infeasible in transductive learning (Zhou et al.,
2021). For each batch, a small number of nodes are randomly sampled, their neighbourhoods are
extracted in a breadth-first manner using the neighbourhood function N , and message passing
is conducted in the corresponding subgraphs. Consequently, the weight matrices are updated
more frequently (after processing each batch rather than the entire dataset), leading to faster
convergence. Utilizing GPUs for processing different batches in parallel further enhances the
training speed.
The two general Aggregate and Update steps described above form the foundation of
so-called Message Passing Neural Networks (MPNN), the most prominent type of spatial GNNs.
These functions are to be determined and may vary for each layer k. By inserting different
Aggregate and Update mechanisms, this general framework for inductive representation
learning can be adapted to accommodate different types of MPNNs, such as GraphSAGE, Graph
Isomorphism Network (GIN), and Graph Attention Network (GAT). We discuss the former two
in the next sections.
3.3.1 GraphSAGE
The general inductive representation learning algorithm was originally proposed for the GraphSAGE model (Hamilton et al., 2017), whose goal is to learn a function that generates embeddings
by sampling and aggregating (SAmple and aggreGatE) features from a node’s local neighbourhood. The neighbourhood function N uniformly samples a fixed-size set of neighbours at each
depth k, which implies that not every neighbour contributes to the embedding of a node. The
idea is that informative embeddings can be derived from only a subset of neighbours, making the

lot of neighbourhood information is lost. When complete structural information is essential, as
in our pattern detection tasks, it is essential to utilize the full neighbourhood. The sample and
aggregate scheme of GraphSAGE is illustrated in Figure 3.2.

We can see that the previous embedding vector is concatenated with the aggregated neighbourhood
vector, which is subsequently fed through a fully connected layer with nonlinear activation function
σ. Note that W(k)is the weight matrix for layer k to be optimized during stochastic gradient
descent. For the Aggregate step, the authors suggest three types of aggregators: mean, maxpooling, and LSTM. The mean aggregator straightforwardly computes the element-wise mean
of the embedding vectors in the neighbourhood, which is nearly equivalent to the convolutional
propagation rule used in the GCN framework; when we skip the concatenation in the Update
rule, we essentially get an inductive variant of the GCN model! The max-pooling aggregator feeds
the neighbours’ embeddings through a fully connected neural network and takes the element-wise
maximum. Finally, the LSTM aggregator, as the name suggests, utilizes a Long Short Term
Memory network within the aggregation mechanism to further enhance the expressive capabilities
of the model. Since LSTMs are not inherently symmetric (i.e., they are not permutation invariant)
due to processing inputs as a sequence, the authors adapt the LSTMs to operate on an unordered
set by simply applying the LSTMs to a random permutation of the node’s sampled neighbours.
This approach disregards any sequential ordering that may persist in the data, which is correct
for most applications that deal with static input graphs. However, for dynamic networks it seems
beneficial to allow the LSTMs to learn the sequential order that persist between edges, which is
what our proposed LSTM aggregator detailed in Section 4.4 aims to do.
In their experiments, the authors demonstrate that GraphSAGE is effective in a wide range
of node classification tasks from multiple domains, using data of citation networks, Reddit posts,
and protein interactions. They specifically test on such dynamic graphs, showcasing the inductive
power of the architecture, yielding significantly better results than DeepWalk while being 10-100
times faster, depending on the neighbourhood sampling size. In the experiment with the protein
interactions dataset, the authors explicitly test the generalization capabilities of the inductive
learning framework across multiple graphs.

3.3.2 Graph Isomorphism Network
In their attempt to understand the representational properties and limitations of GNNs, Xu
et al. (2019) developed a theoretical framework for analyzing the expressive power of GNNs in
capturing different graph structures. They present a MPNN architecture that is provably the most
expressive among the class of GNNs, namely the Graph Isomorphism Network (GIN). The GIN
model generalizes the Weisfeiler-Lehman graph isomorphism test (Lehman and Weisfeiler, 1968),
a heuristic test for the existence of an isomorphism between two graphs, thus achieving maximum
discriminative power among GNNs. The authors utilize multi-layer perceptrons (MLPs) to model
and learn the functions comprising the Aggregate and Update steps in the message passing
mechanism. Since a MLP can represent the composition of functions, the node-wise propagation
rule can be written as a single step, as shown in Equation 3.5.

3.4 GNN Techniques for Graph Pattern Finding
In their paper Provably Powerful Graph Neural Networks for Directed Multigraphs, Egressy et al.
(2024) propose a set of simple and intuitive techniques that can transform any MPNN into powerful
directed multigraph neural networks with provable properties. They show both experimentally
and theoretically that GNNs can identify any directed subgraph pattern when equipped with
(1) ego IDs, (2) heterogeneous message passing, and (3) port numbering. The combination of
these three techniques applied to suitably powerful standard MPNN yields so-called universal
GNNs – those that can distinguish any two non-isomorphic (sub-)graphs, while not mistakenly
distinguishing any two isomorphic (sub-)graphs.
We now explain these techniques. Since we will not be focussing on the multigraph setting
(see Section 5.1), we leave out port numbering (Sato et al., 2019) from this discussion, whose
intent is to distinguish parallel edges.
3.4.1 Modelling Node Identity
First, the authors propose to incorporate node identity into the message passing, which seems
essential for detecting subgraph patterns that consist of (undirected) cycles. A natural approach
would be to assign the unique node index i ∈ {1, . . . , n} of each node as node ID and to use
one-hot encoding vectors vi of length n, with v[i] = 1 and 0 elsewhere, as node input features.
While this yields a universal GNN, it heavily relies on the initial ordering of the nodes, of which
there are n! possible permutations. Consequently, nodes with identical structural neighbourhoods
fail to be mapped to the same embedding, resulting in low generalization capability (Egressy and
Wattenhofer, 2022), rendering this approach unsuitable for the inductive setting. The same issue
arises when assigning random features (Abboud et al., 2020; Sato et al., 2021) as input node
features.
However, functions that can assign node ID vectors inductively have been proposed. The
ID-GNN-Fast method of You et al. (2021) injects node identity information via augmented node
features using cycle counts, efficiently computable through powers of a graph’s adjacency matrix.
A similar method is proposed by Egressy and Wattenhofer (2022), who precompute positional
node embeddings. Here, the input graph is embedded into a Euclidean space approximating l∞
and the coordinate locations are used as node features.
Chapter 3. Graph Neural Networks 19
The more straightforward approach taken by Egressy et al. (2024) is to set the so-called ego
ID feature of a specific seed node to be 1, while all other nodes in its neighbourhood are assigned
an ego ID of 0. The idea is intuitive: by “marking” a “center” node with a distinct binary feature,
this node can recognize when a sequence of messages cycles back around to it. As a result, the
GNN can detect the cycles a node is part of. Note how the ego ID is a scalar that can be easily
concatenated to already existing node features and whose value dynamically changes based on
whether it is sampled as a seed node, meaning it is the sampled node in mini-batch training
whose neighbourhood is extracted and for which we want to make a prediction. In practice, the
implementation of ego IDs can be seen as a preprocessing step integrated with the creation of
batches during mini-batch training, detailed in Section 4.6.
3.4.2 Modelling Edge Directionality
Most traditional graph neural network applications consider the underlying structure of the input
graph to be undirected. In that case, the generic aggregation and update mechanisms are as
formulated in Algorithm 1, where the neighbourhood function N (v) simply returns the set of all
neighbours of v, which includes both nodes connected by an incoming edge and an outgoing edge,
i.e. N (v) = Nin(v) ∪ Nout(v). As a result, the message passing occurs in a bidirectional manner,
termed bidirectional message passing: messages traverse in both directions over an edge, and both
endpoints aggregate each other’s embeddings. However, a significant drawback of this approach
is that it does not consider edge directionality, even though this can be crucial information. In
the domain of financial networks and money laundering, differentiating between the sender and
the receiver is paramount. The ML subgraph patterns we aim to identify are partly characterized
by their suspicious combination of edge directions.
Alternatively, one could consider a strategy where the message passing strictly follows the
direction of the edges, which we refer to as directional message passing. In this approach, a
node sends its embedding solely along its outgoing edges while aggregating messages received
exclusively through its incoming edges, as illustrated in Equation 3.6.

The aim is to conduct message passing in both directions while still indicating the edge

a separate message-passing layer for the incoming and outgoing edges, respectively. Since this is
equivalent to using a relational GNN with two edge types (Schlichtkrull et al., 2018) and their
implementation involves converting the underlying network to a heterogeneous graph, we refer to

Chapter 3. Graph Neural Networks 20
approach. By treating the aggregations of the different edge types separately, the aggregation
function of one edge type lacks access to the embeddings of the other edge type. While this
certainly helps the model to discern the edge directions in ML patterns, it sacrifices the flexibility
to learn correlations between oppositely directed edges since the aggregation procedure cannot
cope with both edge types simultaneously. The latter is especially crucial when we want to model
time dependencies between incoming and outgoing transactions. To solve this issue, we introduce
a novel message passing scheme that allows the simultaneous aggregation of both edges types
while preserving directionality. We refer to this approach as signed message passing and it is
described in Section 4.2.
3.4.3 Modelling Weights
As is often the case in network domains, we can associate weights to the edges. Although we
do not specify what these weights represent, they could reflect various factors in the context
of a financial network, such as the pair-wise similarity between two nodes (for instance, based
on account-based features, transaction behaviour, etc.), the transaction volume, the frequency
of interactions, or a combination. A way of handling such weights is to include the weights as
an edge feature co-embedded with the node features. Hu et al. (2020) extend the GIN model
described in Section 3.3.2 to incorporate edge features into the aggregation procedure as follows:

3.4.4 Modelling Time
To the best of our knowledge, there is no previous work that aims to use GNNs to detect subgraph
patterns that exhibit explicit temporal characteristics. Since an edge in the financial network
represents a transaction, each edge can be associated with a specific timestamp indicating when
the transaction occurred. While various methods for temporal modelling in AML, such as sliding
time windows, have been discussed in Chapter 2, a straightforward way for incorporating time is
to include the timestamps as edge features in the model, similar to the approach for edge weights
described previously. However, this only deals with time implicitly by making the temporal
information available to the model. Instead, we propose to model the temporal dependencies
between transactions explicitly by utilizing LSTMs in the aggregation step. Our approach, along
with other modifications to these GNN techniques, are described in the next chapter.
