 Δ H, enthalpy; BD, breakdown viscosity; CPV, cool paste viscosity; HPV, hot paste viscosity; PT, pasting temperature; PV, peak viscosity; SB, setback viscosity; R, retrogradation range; T c, conclusion temperature of gelatinization; T cR, conclusion temperature of retrogradation; T o, onset temperature of gelatinization; T oR, onset temperature of retrogradation; T p, peak temperature of gelatinization; T pR, peak temperature of retrogradation. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Compared with other starches (e.g., tuber, cereal, legumes, and aquatic plants starch), potato starch shows relatively lower HPV (1687 cP vs. 1557–3258 cP) and PT (67.87°C vs. 68.13–83.47°C), but higher PV (10,048 cP vs. 1818–9672 cP), CPV (3479 cP vs. 2180–4443 cP), BD (8360 cP vs. 165–4706 cP), and SB (1791 cP vs. 623–1567 cP) (Wang et al., 2018). These variations in pasting properties among potato and other starches may be due to: (1) the granule diameter of potato starch is relatively larger (10–50 μm) than other plant starches (4–25 μm) (Wang et al., 2018), which is easier to reach close-packing concentration to decrease PT and increase PV (Reyniers et al., 2020), as well as easier to lower viscosity with decreasing temperature; (2) type B crystal form of potato starch allows to contain more moisture and lead to higher PV; (3) positive charge from high content of phosphorus group exists in potato starch, causing higher PV (Zaidul et al., 2007). 
 
 
 
 
 4.2 Gelatinization and retrogradation properties 
 
 Potato starch gelatinization is an unstable thermodynamic system, and starch chains in a disordered state after gelatinizating tend to repolymerize to form a more thermodynamically stable ordered state (Rezler & Poliszko, 2010). Differed from amylopectin in water absorption, the crystalline structure of amylose would disrupt and result in a loss of birefringence properties (Parker & Ring, 2001). Continued heating would advance expansion of particles, melt of crystals, and arrangement of chains from ordered to disordered, and correspondingly results in increasing molecular motion and completing separation of amylose and amylopectin (Figure  4) (Wang & Copeland, 2013). During gelatinization, potato starch expanded more in length than width and presented a faster structural resolution than cereal starches (Schirmer et al., 2013). Contrary to gelatinization, retrogradation of potato starch is the process of disorder amorphous starch transferred into order crystalline starch, which have short-term and long-term stages (Chang et al., 2021). During retrogradation, starch chains recombine and form a double helix at cooling phase before packing these double helix into crystals (Wang, Li, et al., 2015). 
 
 
 
 
 Schematic diagram of potato starch gelatinization and retrogradation. 
 
 
 
 The gelatinization and retrogradation properties of potato starch are always represented by differential scanning calorimetry, including onset ( T o), peak ( T p), conclusion ( T c) temperature, and enthalpy change (Δ H) parameters (Vamadevan & Bertoft, 2015). Obviously, starch gelatinization and retrogradation properties greatly differ among potato varieties and planting areas (Table  4). Literatures have shown that T o varied from 52.22°C (Wang et al., 2018) to 67.6°C (Ahmed et al., 2018), T p was 61.4°C (Waterschoot et al., 2016) to 71.1°C (Ahmed et al., 2018), T c ranged from 67.7°C (Jane et al., 1999) to 79.7°C (Chung et al., 2014), and Δ H differed from 6.5 J/g (Wang et al., 2018) to 22.2 J/g (Waterschoot et al., 2016), respectively. Compared with other plant starches (e.g., arrowroot, cassava, Chinese yam, fern root, kidney bean, lotus seed, taro, water chestnut and corn starch), potato starch shows relatively lower T o (52.2°C vs. 50.6–77.7°C), T c (74.6°C vs. 75.0–95.3°C), and Δ H (6.51 J/g vs. 4.6–13.2 J/g) (Wang et al., 2018). Meanwhile, potato starch gelatinization is also greatly affected by amylose, granule size, crystallinity, and chain length of starch (Zhu & Liu, 2020). For example, T o of potato starch shows positive correlations to amylose content, which may be due to the formation of amorphous lamella from soluble amylose in water during gelatinization (Zhu & Liu, 2020). Lower degree of intergranular organization of potato starch granules could result in lower Δ H (Ahmed et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2018). Long chain of potato amylopectin especially external long-chain (B3 chain) length would express higher gelatinization temperature, while the molar mass fraction of shorter B1 chains is negatively correlated with Δ H (Zhu & Liu, 2020). Contrary, total inner chain length of potato starch is negatively correlated with T c, but positively with Δ H (Zhu & Liu, 2020). Moreover, higher double-helical arrangement of chains in amylose and amylopectin would have higher gelatinization temperatures (Martinez et al., 2019). 
 
 Comparatively, retrograded potato starch shows lower T oR (42.8°C) and Δ H R (5.4 J/g) than that of normal starch (56.0°C and 16.0 J/g) (Lu et al., 2016). The lower T oR, T pR, and T cR of retrograded starch than that of gelatinization may indicate that the changes in starch structure is irreversible (Figure  3; Li et al., 2020a). Degree of retrogradation expressed by the percentage of Δ H and Δ H R ranges from 10.6% (Ahmed et al., 2018) to 77.0% (Przetaczek-Roznowska, 2017) (Table  4). Similar with gelatinization, retrogradation of potato starch is also closely related with amylose and amylopectin. Amylose may act as the core of amylopectin recrystallization, facilitating the retrogradation (Zhu & Liu, 2020). Longer inner chain length could result in higher level of amylopectin recrystallization (Zhu & Liu, 2020). The molar percentages of amylopectin short B1 chains are negatively correlated with Δ H R, whereas those of amylopectin long B3 chains are positively related with T pR and T cR of retrograded potato starches, suggesting longer chains of amylopectin could increase the flexibility of potato starch molecules to realign and reorder during retrogradation (Zhu & Liu, 2020). Retrogradation ratio increased from 4.18 to 17.14% when degree of starch gelatinization rose from 56.11 to 90.56%, respectively (Xu et al., 2021), demonstrating the significant influence of degree of starch gelatinization on properties of retrogradation potato starch. In addition, potato starch would also undergo retrogradation due to the continuous movement of molecules during long-term storage, which is called long-term retrogradation (Liu et al., 2020). Chen et al. ( 2020) reported cooked potato starch stored at cycle temperature was more likely to produce retrograded starch than that at fixed temperature. 
 
 
 
 
 4.3 Swelling power and solubility 
 
 Swelling power and solubility are another crucial properties of potato starch for industrial production (Nagar et al., 2021; Vamadevan & Bertoft, 2015), which are always used to perceive the intercourse between water molecules and chains of starch in the semi-crystalline regions of granules during heating (Wang et al., 2018). When potato starch is heated in excess water, the crystal structure disrupted and water molecules are linked to exposed hydroxyl groups of amylose and amylopecin through hydrogen bonds, resulting in particle swelling and solubility (Dupuis & Liu, 2019). 
 
 The swelling power and solubility of different potato starches are presented in Table  3. The swelling power varies from 0.8 g/g in 60°C (Reddy et al., 2015) to 51.2 g/g in 90°C (Shen et al., 2022), and solubility ranges from 1.2 to 14.8% in 50°C (Table  3; Shen et al., 2022). Typically, the swelling power and solubility of potato starch would increase with raising temperature, due to the entrance of water molecules into starch granules. For example, Shen et al. ( 2022) found swelling power (2.1–51.2 g/g) and solubility (1.2–14.8%) of potato starch both significantly increased with temperature (50–90°C). Compared with other native starches, potato starch shows higher swelling power (33.41%) than that of banana (15.79%) and rice (17.58%) starch because of the weak internal bonding and the existence of ionizable esterified phosphate group (Yadav et al., 2016). Li and Yeh ( 2001) reported that swelling power increased with T (current temperature)/ T P, which is due to the beginning temperature of disruption of potato starch granule. 
 
 The swelling power and solubility of potato starch are dramatically affected by chains of amylose and amylopectin and minor compositions in starch. In detail, the swelling power of potato starch shows positive and negative correlations with long-chain amylose and short-chain amylose, but they are weak positively correlated with external chain length and inter-block chain length of amylopectin (Vamadevan & Bertoft, 2020). The phosphorus shows positive correlation with swelling properties but is negatively correlated to solubility of potato starch (Karim et al., 2007), which is caused by negatively charged phosphate ester groups within the potato starch granules (Jane et al., 1999). The lipid and protein existed in starch could inhibit the occurrence of swelling (Putseys et al., 2010; Simkova et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2020). Similarly, swelling force and solubility are inversely and positively correlated with potato starch granule diameter, respectively, which might be due to the differences in amylose content and granule morphology (Singh & Kaur, 2004). 
 
 
 
 
 4.4 Digestibility 
 
 Digestibility of potato starch significantly influences potato nutritional function. The digestibility of potato starch is affected by multiple factors, such as amylose/amylopectin ratio, fine structure, granule structure, helical structure, degree of gelatinization, and retrogadation (Chung et al., 2014). The detection methods of starch digestibility could be divided into in vitro and in vivo. Potato starch could be divided into three types based on the digestibility and hydrolysis by α-amylase and pullulanase in vitro, namely rapidly digestible starch (less than 20 min), slowly digestible starch (between 20 and 120 min), and resistant starch (RS; more than 120 min) (Bello-Perez et al., 2020; Kim et al., 2017). 
 
 The existence of RS has great effects on potato starch digestibility. The RS content of potato significantly differs among potato cultivars and planting conditions (Table  1). It generally ranges from 3.62% (local cultivars; Reddy et al., 2015) to a maximum of 92.9% (Imilla blanca; Martinez et al., 2019). The RS content of 12 potato cultivars is 71.1–86.1%, also indicating great effects of location × year (Bach et al., 2013). Normally, raw potato starch has higher RS content (69.59%) than corn (1.44%), rice (0.31%), wheat (1.07%), and tapioca (1.77%) starch (Romano et al., 2016). RS content of uncooked potato starches (78.9–92.9%) is significantly higher than that of cooked starches (1.7–8.0%) (Martinez et al., 2019). 
 
 Other factors like crystallinity and the amylose/amylopectin ratio in starch could also affect RS content of potato starch (Chung et al., 2014; Kim et al., 2017; Li et al., 2020a). Starch granules with higher crystallinity have fewer amorphous lamella, would be easily accessed by enzymes and rise RS content (Chung et al., 2006). The hydrolysis rate of large (50.03 μm), medium (29.44 μm), and small granules (11.04 μm) of potato starch is about 7.5, 17.5, and 24.0%, respectively, indicating a negative correlations between hydrolysis and starch particle size of potato starch (Dhital et al., 2010). 
 
 
 
 
 5 BIOSYNTHESIS OF POTATO STARCH 
 
 Potato starch biosynthesis as a highly complex biochemical process requires synergy of multiple enzymes including AGPase, SSs, SBE, and DBE (Reyniers et al., 2020). In addition, GWD and PWD play important roles in potato starch phosphorylation at the C-6 and C-3 position. These main starch synthesis-related enzymes in potato mainly exist in amyloplast except for AGPase that both distribute in and out of amyloplast (Li et al., 2017; Stensballe et al., 2008). Generally, each type of enzymes have several various isomers and special functions. The synthesis process of potato amylose and amylopectin could be briefly described as follow (Figure  5): (1) α-glucose-6-phosphate (Glc-6p) is transformed into α-glucose-1-phosphate (Glc-1p) by phosphoglucomutase (PGM) before transformation into ADP-glucose (ADPGlc) via AGPase and adenosine triphosphate; (2) most of Glc-1p and a few Glc-6p are transported from cytoplasm to amyloplast; (3) long chains are synthesized with SSs and ADPGlc, in which straight chain is subsequently converted to branches by SBE or excess branches are trimmed by DBE (Qu et al., 2018). 
 
 
 
 
 Potato starch biosynthesis. Redraw based on Qu et al. ( 2018) and Reyniers et al. ( 2020). 
 
 
 
 
 
 5.1 AGPase 
 
 AGPase (EC 2.7.7.27) is the first enzyme during starch biosynthesis pathway, catalyzing the conversion of glucose-1-phosphate (Glc-1p) and ATP into ADPGlc, which is the monomer of starch formation and substrates for further starch synthesis, and remaining the inorganic pyrophosphate in amyloplasts (Li et al., 2017; Qu et al., 2018; Zeeman et al., 2010). AGPase mainly exists as a heterotetramer in potato tubers (Saripalli & Gupta, 2015), which could be divided into two large subunits and two small subunits (Tetlow, 2011). A quantity of AGPase-large subunits concentrate to their specific expression while AGPase-small subunits have organ-specific expression patterns for its multiple isoforms (Tetlow, 2011). Apparently, the activity and expression of potato AGPase are closely correlated with starch content. Lloyd et al. ( 1999) reported AGPase antisense potato lines had lower amylose content (13.0–15.9%) and granule diameter (12.8–18.0 μm) than those of their mother line (18.7% and 27.9 μm), which may be caused by reduction in ADPGlc supplement. Müller-Röber et al. ( 1992) found the AGPase antisense lines with lower starch content had higher sucrose and glucose content, suggesting AGPase was the first enzyme required for starch synthesis from carbohydrates. The encoding genes of AGPase-large subunits and AGPase-small subunits are AGPaseS and AGPaseB, respectively (Li et al., 2013). Two single-strand conformation polymorphisms fragment in AGPaseS (AGPsS-9a and AGPsS-10b) are positively correlated with starch content, while another fragment AGPsS-10a is negatively correlated with starch content and starch yield (Li et al., 2013). Tiessen et al. ( 2002) also reported that the presence of glycerate-3-phosphate (3PGA) could result in approximately 2.5-fold increase of AGPase activity in wild potato tubers when compared with the potatoes with absence of 3GPA. Furthermore, low inorganic phosphate would inhibit potato AGPase activity (Boehlein et al., 2013). 
 
 
 
 
 5.2 SSs 
 
 SSs (EC 2.4.1.21) catalyze the transfer of ADPglucose glucosyl moiety to nonreducing end of existing glucosyl chain (Pfister & Zeeman, 2016). SSs in potato have two major isoforms, GBSS and soluble starch synthase (SSS). GBSS could promote synthesis of amylose and the extra-long-chain of amylopectin, while SSS could increase the synthesis of most long chain of amylopectin. In detail, SSs in potato starch could be generally divided into GBSS (∼60 kDa), SSI (∼57 kDa), SSII (∼77 kDa), and SSIII (∼110–140 kDa) (Nazarian-Firouzabadi & Visser, 2017). The content of GBSS and SSII is the highest among starch synthesis-related enzymes in potato (Helle et al., 2019). 
 
 
 
 5.2.1 GBSS 
 
 GBSS always tightly binds with starch granules and is mainly responsible for synthesis and extend of amylose chains (Wang et al., 2015). GBSS has a progressive mode of synthesis, allowing to add more than one glucose unit each time from substrate to synthesize long linear chains (Nielsen et al., 2018). GBSS would extend chains of amylose when amylose presented, otherwise it would lengthen the long branches of amylopectin (Denyer et al., 1999). GBSS predominantly consists of two isoforms: GBSSI and GBSSII (Li et al., 2017). In potato, GBSSI accounts for 95% of GBSS and mainly expresses in all stages of development in tubers, whereas GBSSII mostly expresses in young embryos (Dry et al., 1992). Transcript level of GBSSII decreases with increased GBSS I transcript level in the later development stage, in which GBSSII content is slightly higher than that of GBSSI in young embryos (Dry et al., 1992). Deletion of GBSSI gene in potato would result in decrease of GBSSI expression, directly leading to reduction or complete disappearance of amylose accumulation in potato tubers (Veillet et al., 2019). Loss of GBSS activity would result in a crack in starch granule that arises from the central hilum (Edwards et al., 2002). Brummell et al. ( 2015) found that expression loss of GBSS would significantly decrease average chain length of potato amylopectin and amylose content. Moreover, Andersson et al. ( 2017) reported that mutation of different alleles in GT1 and protospacer adjacent motif target region would bring about loss of GBSS activity and reduction of amylose/amylopectin ratio. 
 
 
 
 
 5.2.2 SSS 
 
 SSS in potato has six different major isoforms (SSI–VI), and several other isoforms such as SSII (SSIIa, SSIIb, SSIIc), SSIII (SSIIIa, SSIIIb), SSSIV (SSIVa, SSIVb) (Tetlow, 2011). Among these isoforms, only four isomers (SSI, SSII, SSIII, and SSIV) have been extensively studied, while possible role of SSV and SSVI on potato tuber starch biosynthesis is relatively less reported (Van Harsselaar et al., 2017). SSI, SSII, SSIII, and SSIV are thought to be exclusively involved in amylopectin biosynthesis. Typically, SSI, SSII, and SSIII predominantly participate in synthesis of short chain (DP 4–12), medium chain (B1 chain, DP 12–24), and long chain (B2 chain, DP ≥ 30), respectively (Edwards et al., 2002; Tetlow, 2011), whereas SSIV may affect the initiation of granule formation (Zeeman et al., 2010). 
 
 SSI is mainly expressed in potato leaves and has few effects on potato tuber starch (Qu et al., 2018). SSII is the major component of SSS in potato starch, accounting for almost 80% of SSS activity (Marshall et al., 1996; Nazarian-Firouzabadi & Visser, 2017). Interestingly, the loss of SSI activity or inhibition of SSII both unchanged potato starch structure, implying the partial function compensation of other SSs (Nazarian-Firouzabadi & Visser, 2017). However, downregulation of single enzyme or synthase activity such as less than 15% loss of SSII activity has not had significant effect on potato starch yield (Edwards et al., 1995; Nazarian-Firouzabadi & Visser, 2017). In addition, SSIII is also thought to be involved in the initiation of starch granules (Pfister & Zeeman, 2016). Compared with the maternal lines, the proportions of A and B1 chains in amylopectin increase, while B2 and B3 chains decrease in SSII and SSIII-inhibited potato lines, indicating that SSII and SSIII mainly synthesize B2 andB3 chains (Lloyd et al., 1999). The growth loop structure of starch granules in SSIII-inhibited lines is also irregular and fractured, suggesting that SSIII inhibition resulted in the absence of amylopectin and semi-crystalline layer in potato starch granules (Fulton et al., 2002). Similar with GBSS, reduction in SS activity also could result in the presence of cracks inside the potato starch granule (Edwards et al., 2002). Nonetheless, the roles of SSV–VI in potato starch synthesis have not been clearly documented (Van Harsselaar et al., 2017). SSV may be mainly tuber-specifically expressed and coexpressed in potato tubers. Although potato SSV without catalytical activity via modifying SSV sequence, it still has specific enzymatic function during starch synthesis (Van Harsselaar et al., 2017). Additionally, SSVI may present similar functions of SSIV in elongating chain of potato starch (Helle et al., 2018). 
 
 
 
 
 
 5.3 SBE 
 
 SBEs (EC 2.4.1.18) are enzymes regulating the branched chains synthesis of amylopectin. New branched chains generated by SBE are via (1) detaching the α-1,4-glucan chain from polyglucans and (2) transferring the released chain onto an acceptor chain via a-1,6-glucan linkage (Li et al., 2017; Qu et al., 2018). SBEs could add a new branch point to the glucan extension reaction of SSs to generate a new nonreducing end, affecting the polymer structure and synthesized amount of α-glucan (Tetlow & Emes, 2014). SBEs have two major classes, SBEI and SBEII (also known as SBE A and SBE B), which are divided based on the primary amino acid (Tetlow, 2011). In potatoes, the content of SBEI is normally higher than SBEII content (Tuncel et al., 2019; Van Harsselaar et al., 2017). Potato SBEI and SBEII could both branch chains and generate chains of DP 6–7 and DP 11–14, and SBEI moreover could product chains of DP 29–30 in starch (Rydberg et al., 2001). Potato with high SBE expression level would have higher yields may be as a result of high turnover of Glc1-P (Kaminski et al., 2012). Edwards et al. ( 2002) reported that transgenic potato line with higher SBE activity (13.8 μmol/min·g) led to higher starch content (112 vs. 83 mg/g). Similarly, mutation of Sbe results in almost no amylopectin existed in transgenic potato lines, suggesting that amylopectin formation is inseparable from the presence of SBE (Zhao et al., 2021). Safford et al. ( 1998) found that reduction in SBE activity (from 5 to 0.5 u/g) would decrease the peak CLD length (from DP 18 to DP 24) of potato starch. Compared with wide type, overexpression of SBEII in potato increases the content of chains with DP ≤ 12 of amylopectin especially the chains of DP 6 (19–56% increase) and greatly reduces amylose content, starch pasting, and thermal properties due to crystallinity change (Brummell et al., 2015). Low expression of SBEI and SBEII would decrease potato starch content from 75.5 to 67.9% (Zhao et al., 2018). However, inhibition of SBE expression in different potatoes could result in higher amylose content (26–49%) than that in wide-types (23%) (Menzel et al., 2015). 
 
 
 
 
 5.4 DBE 
 
 DBEs are a class of glucan-modifying enzymes, debranching the α-(1→6) glycosidic linkages of starch (Li et al., 2017; Qu et al., 2018). DBEs have two different major forms, known as isoamylase-type DBE (ISA; EC 3.2.1.68) and pullulanase-type DBE (PUL; EC 3.2.1.142; Qu et al., 2018). ISAs usually remove excessively branched and improper branches of amylopectin, while PUL cleaves the α-1,6-linkages of polyglucans in pullulan and AP rather than glycogen (Tetlow, 2011; Qu et al., 2018). ISAs have three isoforms, ISAI, ISAII, and ISAIII, in which ISAI and ISAII could probably develop amylopectin crystallinity by trimming inadequately spaced glucan branches, thus allowing tighter packing of glucan chains (Hussain et al., 2003; Tetlow, 2011). 
 
 In potatoes, ISAI, ISAIII, and PUL show different roles on amylopectin synthesis. ISAI majorly focuses on the long external chain (B3 chain), while ISAIII and PUL act on short external chain (B1 chain) (Zeeman et al., 2010). ISAII generally has higher expression than ISAI and ISAIII, which could in company with ISAI to debranch soluble glucan for effective granule formation during starch synthesis (Hussain et al., 2003). Loss of ISAI or ISAII would cause the accumulation of phytoglycogen (Li et al., 2017). For example, Ferreira et al. ( 2017) found more than 50% reduction in potato starch content but great increase in starch granule size with reduced ISAI, ISAII, and ISAIII activity. Bustos et al. ( 2004) reported antisense expression of potato ISAI and ISAII would increase the number of small starch granule, especially those granules of less than 1 μm, but not alter starch CLD. These results demonstrated that ISA could expand diameter of potato starch granules by controlling formation of starch granules. 
 
 
 
 
 5.5 GWD 
 
 Phosphorylation as the only natural covalent modification of starch determines the physicochemical properties of potato starch due to its significant role in starch degradation. Generally, two distinct isoforms of starch phosphorylating enzymes, GWD1 (EC 2.7.9.4) and PWD (or GWD3; EC 2.7.9.5), mainly catalyze the addition of phosphate groups to the C-6 and C-3 position of the glycosyl residues, respectively (Chen, Hawkins, Seung, 2021). However, GWD2 has not been associated with transitory starch degradation due to its cytosolic localization. Potato tubers with specific expression of GWD gene have a higher proportion of phosphorylated starch (7.8–33.5 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch) than cereal starches (0–1.0 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch) and other tuber starches (2.5 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch for cassava and 4.6 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch for arrow root) (Blennow et al., 2000; Blennow & Engelsen, 2010). Kozlov et al. ( 2007) reported that the GWD antisense potato lines showed low content of phosphorylated starch (2.25–2.31 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch) but higher content of amylose content (36.0–36.5%) than that (14.1 nmol Glc6 P/mg in starch and 31.1%) of maternal line. Additionally, suppressed GWD expression in transgenic potato lines would decrease PV, BD, and CPV, but had no significant effects on starch gelatinization (Wickramasinghe et al., 2009). Heterologous expression of Arabidopsis thaliana GWD2 and GWD3 in potato tubers would alter starch granule morphology, but not change the starch phosphate content (Xu et al., 2018). 
 
 
 
 
 5.6 Other enzymes 
 
 Apart from AGPase, SSs, SBE, DBE, and GWD, some other enzymes such as sucrose synthase (SuSy), UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (UGPase), and starch phosphorylase also have great roles on synthesis of potato starch. SuSy (EC:2.4.1.13) is the enzyme catalyzing reversible conversion between nucleoside diphosphate glucose (UDPGlc), fructose, nucleoside diphosphate, and sucrose (Schmolzer et al., 2016). SuSy could control the transfer pathway from sucrose to starch as well as affect the AGPase-mediated synthesis process of ADPGlc (Schmolzer et al., 2016). Loss of SuSy in potatoes would result in loss of UDP-glucose and reduction in starch content (Ferreira & Sonnewald, 2012). UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (EC:2.7.7.9) is widely distributed in potatoes, mediating the transfer from UDPGlc to Glc-1P and ADPG during starch synthesis (Geigenberger et al., 2004). Increased UGPase activity resulting from low temperature (7°C) is closely related to the low temperature-induced saccharification of stored potatoes (Hironaka et al., 2005). Starch phosphorylase (E.C. 2.4.1.1) mainly catalyzes a reversible reaction of glucosyl units from Glc-1P to (1→4)-α-linked glc chains with nonreducing end (Li et al., 2017). 
 
 
 
 
 6 APPLICATION OF POTATO STARCH 
 
 Currently, attentions on potato starch used for food and pharmaceutical purposes have rapidly increased due to its low cost, availability, biodegradability, and environmental friendliness (Figure  6). In general, food consumption, industrial utilization, seed potato, and animal feed account for about 68, 14, 8, and 4% of annual potato yields. In particular, potato starch is mainly used as additive and raw degradable material in food utilization, while tablet disintegrating agent, drug carrier, and medic material for medicine use. 
 
 
 
 
 Application of potato starch in different fields. 
 
 
 
 
 
 6.1 Staple and snack food 
 
 Potato starch has always been isolated as a raw material for making various staple foods and snacks, such as potato noodle, bread, chips, and fries. Saito et al. ( 2019) reported a type of noodle made with potato starch, which had approximately 12.1–44.4% higher water retention ability than noodles made from mung bean starch and wheat flour, and better mechanical properties after cooking than that of noodle with mung bean starch. A great decrease in cooking loss (from 8.56 to 5.89%) and ratio of broken noodles (from 13.33 to 8.89%) were found in heat-moisture treated noodle made from potato starch, demonstrating an improvement of cooking properties and taste quality of gluten-free noodles (Yang et al., 2022). The bread made from potato starch shows higher holes area (4.1%) than that of bread with wheat starch (2.4%) and achieves more similar structure with bread made with wheat starch than that of bread made with rice and tapioca starches (Horstmann et al., 2016). Meanwhile, potato starch also could be used to create lower glycemic index (GI) food, such as foods for diabetes, because of its more RS content and high gelatinization temperature (Ahmed et al., 2018). Margarine instant pudding made with potato starch has lower gelatinization temperature (69.75–70.89°C vs. 81.8°C), higher PV (5825–9239 cP vs. 2704 cP) and CPV (4411–4891 cP vs. 2724 cP) than grain starch, which is more conducive to maintaining the high paste viscosity of pudding (Singh et al., 2021). Zhang et al. ( 2021) reported that the content of penetrated surface oil and structure oil in fried potato chips reduced to 27.31 and 22.25%, respectively, after ultrasonic treatment processing on potato starch. Nath et al. ( 2007) developed a snack with air puffing process and potato starch to essentially reduce the health problems associated with traditional fried foods. 
 
 
 
 
 6.2 Food additive 
 
 Notably, because of the macromolecular structure and unique properties of potato starch, they are beneficial to improve properties of some products as food additive such as thickener in yogurt (Altemimi, 2018), sugar substitute (Kapusniak & Nebesny, 2017), fat substitute (Hu et al., 2019), which aim to reducing calorie intake and GI. The yogurt with high concentration (0.75–1.00%) of potato starch shows better antisyneresis performance (1.95–2.00 g/100 g) than that (4.32–4.38 g/100 g) of low concentration (0.25–0.5%), and sensory of yogurt with 1% potato starch was like that of yogurt with 0.6% gelatin (Altemimi, 2018). Kapusniak and Nebesny ( 2017) reported that the enzyme-resistant dextrins by potato starch with microwave heating after acidification had low reducing sugar content (3.6–4%) but high total dietary fiber content (22.8–28.0%), which could replace sugar in soft drink. Similarly, potato starch with 85% amylose could be used to prepare fat substitute by super-heated quenching, showing better texture properties in hardness and cohesiveness (Hu et al., 2019). Addition of food-grade potato starch in fruit and vegetable mousse could generate new soluble dextrin fiber and increase dietary fiber content (Kapusniak et al., 2021). Bortnowska et al. ( 2013) reported that beef sauces with addition of 4% potato starch had better consistency index and model stability than that made of maize starch. Low-salt (1.2%) sausages with addition of potato starch could obtain similar water-binding capacity, color, and texture of high-salt (1.8%) sausages (Grossi et al., 2012). Addition of 16% potato starch into Hairtail Surimi could significantly improve gel properties like water holding capacity (Luo et al., 2020). Moreover, potato starch is also considered as a polysaccharide with no surface activity and acts as a stabilizer in emulsion system (Prochaska et al., 2007). For example, potato starch as an emulsifier could be complexed with materials with negatively charged properties such as protein, to obtain better sensory quality (Dong & Cui, 2021). 
 
 
 
 
 6.3 Food packaging and film 
 
 Compared with synthetic plastic packaging, potato starch-based packaging has advantages of environmentally friendly degradability and less harmful to human body. To improve the functionality of potato starch-based packaging materials, additives like glycerol, cellulose, and gelatin are also usually added to enhance fluidity, hydrophobicity, and mechanical strength (Cheng et al., 2021). The development of 3D printing technology allowed potato starch to create new structures with enough strength. 3D printing food materials based on potato starch show great printing qualities like structural and physicochemical properties (Feng et al., 2018). A nanocomposite film with UV resistant and higher transparency based on potato starch is developed as sustainable package (Balakrishnan et al., 2018). Potato starch can also be made into fiber or cellulose for food packaging (Fonseca et al., 2019). Compared with free carvacrol, the encapsulation of carvacrol with nanofibers made from potato starch significantly increase the thermal stability, delay the peak thermal decomposition rate from 150 to 300°C but kept 83.1% of antioxidant ability with 40% carvacrol loaded (Fonseca et al., 2019). 
 
 Meanwhile, various edible potato starch-films are always made under certain conditions for food storage, such as antibacterial film (Wu et al., 2019). Film made of potato amylose would have better properties in strength, low oxygen permeability and keeping intact, while high amylopectin content may lead to film break (Menzel et al., 2015). The phase separation mechanism of edible biocomposite films made of ≤30 wt% potato starch is nucleation and grow, whereas the starch content >30% then the spinodal decomposition is the dominant mechanism (Podshivalov et al., 2017). Besides, potato starch is also used as substrate to attach microcapsules and pickering emulsions to form functional packaging. For example, potato starch-based film loaded with thyme oil microcapsules could slowly release the active antibacterial ingredient and extend the shelf life of cold meat (Yuan et al., 2021). The edible coatings generated from potato starch (4%) could provide effective antifungal activity and prolong the taste period of stored apples, cucumbers, and tomatoes (Mehyar et al., 2014). Furthermore, Celikci et al. ( 2020) developed an environmentally friendly cardboard adhesive from modified potato starch with best adhesive property of 10.90 MPa strength, implying great potential in recycling of waste potato starch in food industries. 
 
 
 
 
 6.4 Medic fields 
 
 Potato starch also is applied on pharmaceutical and biomedical fields owing to its biocompatibility, total degradability without toxic residues, low cost, wide availability, renewability, and thermoplastic behavior (Zakaria et al., 2017). For example, potato starch is used as antihemorrhagic material to block the bleeding point with less harm as traditional antihemorrhagic, based on its excellent absorb water and expand capacities (Poehnert et al., 2019). The potato starch-based adhesion prevention barrier agent could prevent the formation of adhesions and provide antihemorrhagic ability (Poehnert et al., 2019). The superabsorbent properties of acryloylated potato starch ester grafted with acrylic acid show remarkable water absorption capacity (127 g/g) and potentiality to be antihemorrhagic agents (Mohammed et al., 2014). Potato starch is also introduced as drug carrier in cancer and nasal administration of insulin due to its biocompatibility to human body, which could address the issues like low target specificity and potency of conventional drug delivery system (Chen et al., 2015; Davoodi et al., 2017; Elgaied-Lamouchi et al., 2021) For example, potato starch loaded with thymol after film formation could endow the film with considerable antibacterial properties (Davoodi et al., 2017). Moreover, potato starch could be used as tablet disintegrates, pharmaceutical diluents, and binder glue for tablets (Liu et al., 2017). Tablets mixed with potato starch and potato dextrin (1:1) could completely release diprophylline within 2 h, which is significantly better than that of pure potato starch tablets (released less than 75% after 8H) (Elgaied-Lamouchi et al., 2021). The tablet disintegrated made with 2.5–10% potato starch showed higher ability of crushing strength and drug release efficiency than that of tablet disintegrate made with corn starch (Muazu et al., 2012). In addition, potato starch could also be compounded with other materials to make high-value medical consumables. The vascular grafts generated from potato starch with bacterial cellulose have higher collagen content than that of vessel contained only bacterial cellulose (Liu et al., 2022). The stents made from potato starch could be degraded by salivary amylase and had higher hydrolysis rate (96%) than that (50%) of stents made from maize starch (Beilvert et al., 2014). 
 
 
 
 
 7 CONCLUSIONS 
 
 Potato starch as a unique macromolecule and available environment-friendly polymer is always the focus of carbohydrate research for potato breeding and starch implications in past decades. Based on this review, it is certain that various starch composition, granular structure, types of synthesis-related enzymes, and their expression have great impacts on potato starch physicochemical properties. Nonetheless, information about potato starch metabolism and roles of different starch-related enzyme isomers in potato is still currently limited. For potato starch, priority should be given to understanding the actual structure and composition of amorphous layer and semi-crystalline layer of potato starch granules. With the awareness of environmental protection, further investigation could also focus on the optimization of potato starch-based materials for producing fully biodegradable materials in food packaging and storage. New modification technologies such as biotechnology should be developed to increase safety of potato starch for wide utilization.

# Effect of thermal modifications of potato starch on its selected properties [☆](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0268005X14000599\#aep-article-footnote-id7)

## Highlights

- •
Heating and freezing potato starch suspension cause an increase in the viscosity of pastes prepared.

- •
Dependency of paste viscosity on heating temperature has a character of a polynomial function.

- •
Paste viscosity is positively correlated with the size of swollen starch granules.


## Abstract

Aqueous suspensions prepared from native [potato starch](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/potato-starch) (with the concentration 4 g/100 g) were heated to temperatures of 59, 64, 69, 74, 79, 84, 89 or 94 °C, under continuous stirring. The resultant solutions were cooled, frozen and defrosted, and subjected to analyses.

The heating and freezing of a [potato starch](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/potato-starch) suspension changed its properties, with the direction and extent of these changes depending on the temperature of pre-heating. The re-pasting of the produced starch preparations in a Brabender [viscosimeter](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/viscometer) increased their viscosity to 50% compared to the pastes produced from native starch. The assayed viscosity of the pastes depended on the pre-heating temperature and was changing following the determined second degree polynomial function. The thermal characteristics (DSC) of the analyzed preparations revealed peaks that corresponded to transitions of native starch pasting and retrograded starch [solubilization](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/solubilization). The strength of the produced gels, determined with the use of an oscillatory-rotational [rheometer](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/agricultural-and-biological-sciences/rheometer), was greater than that of gels produced from native starch and depended on the pre-heating temperature, however these changes followed the determined second order polynomial function. Microscope preparations (SEM) of retrograded starch differed significantly in porosity that was also found to depend on the pre-heating temperature. Paste viscosity was positively correlated with the size of gel sacks determined with a laser particle size analyzer (LSA).

## Introduction

Starch is one of the key energetic components in a man's diet. As a result of many thermal processes applied during food production and preparation, in food products starch occurs mainly in the form of paste. Pasting proceeds in a water environment at increased temperatures. It consists of several stages and depends on a variety of factors including, e.g., botanical origin of starch (Singh, Singh, Kaur, Sodhi, & Gill, 2003), content of amylose (Chen, Yu, Kealy, Chen, & Li, 2007), starch–water ratio in the solution (Fukuoka, Ohta, & Watanabe, 2002), temperature (Peng, Zhongdong, & Kennedy, 2007) and the heating rate (Patel & Seetharaman, 2006).

The first stage of pasting involves the swelling of starch granules. The swollen granules are insoluble, however their reversible swelling occurs in water with a temperature of up to 50 °C. In this process starch absorbs water, thereby increasing its volume even by 30% (Leszczyński, 2004). Along with further heating of a starch dispersion, hydrogen bonds responsible for the structural cohesiveness of granules break up, allowing water to penetrate inside the granules and enabling the hydration of linear fragments of amylopectin (Xie, Yu, Chen, & Li, 2008). This process leads to the irreversible swelling of starch granules, the volume of which increases several times (Wurzburg, 2000, pp. 1–17). These phenomena cause the loss of starch crystallinity and an increase in the viscosity of the paste formed. The viscosity reaches the maximum values when dissolved and depolymerized starch substance migrates from the most swollen granules to the solution (Sangeetha & Rai, 2006). These transformations do not proceed simultaneously in all starch granules. In the case of potato starch, pasting proceeds firstly in the largest granules characterized by a lower initial pasting temperature compared to the granules with smaller size (Kaur, Singh, McCarthy, & Singh, 2007). The differences observed in the initial pasting temperatures may be due to, e.g., a various ratio of amylose–amylopectin in granules of various sizes (Singh & Kaur, 2004).

At the final stage of starch pasting, when temperature exceeds 85 °C, the granules are subject to damage (they break up). It leads to depolymerization and dissolution of starch chains, which is accompanied by a decrease in viscosity of the paste being formed. Thus the produced starch paste contains dissolved carbohydrate substance and fragments of starch granules and displays traits typical of the non-Newtonian fluid (Leszczyński, 2004). Rheological properties of a paste produced from potato starch which – considering its chemical structure – is an amylophosphate acid, are determined by many factors, with the most significant ones including: starch granularity, content of amylose, content of phosphorus (Jayakody, Hoover, Liu, & Donner, 2007), types and concentrations of elements saturating starch (Singh, Kaur, & McCarthy, 2007), length of amylopectin chains (Jane et al., 1999), and starch modifications.

Cooling the starch paste reduces the motility of granules in a solution, which results in their approximation and agglomeration as well as in re-increase of paste viscosity. At an appropriate concentration, the paste is subject to gelling and forms compact, gelatinous mass, in which the starch substance absorbs significant quantities of water (Blazek & Copeland, 2008). The storage of starch gels, especially at a temperature approximating 0 °C, causes them to undergo changes called “pastes aging”. The paste is becoming turbid and its viscosity decreases. The gel becomes rigid, its surface is thickening and some water appears on it, which indicates the ongoing phenomenon of syneresis (Charoenrien & Preechathammawong, 2012). These changes are due to starch retrogradation (Karim, Norziah, & Seow, 2000), that consists in the transition of part of dissolved starch into the insoluble fraction. In the course of the retrogradation process, the straight chains of starch dissolved in water (amylose in particular) are gradually stranding into helices and then bind into double helices that are strengthened with hydrogen bonds, with simultaneous dehydration. Within a few hours of gel storage, these helices are subject to aggregation. They form permanent, thermostable and insoluble in water crystalline structures (Zięba, 2009, pp. 67–71).

Hydrothermal modification of starch has been addressed in many works that were aimed at elucidating the impact of heat-moisture treatment on starches (Juansang et al., 2012, Varatharajana et al., 2010) and that of the temperature close to the pasting temperature on a water starch suspension (annealing) (Rocha, Felizardo, Jane, & Franco, 2012). Some other works have been focused on partial or incomplete gelatinization (Chung, Lim, & Lim, 2006), while others on the properties of starch paste that had been subjected to cyclic freezing and defrosting (Wang et al., 2013) and of spray-dried starch after partial gelatinization (Fua et al., 2012, Fua et al., 2013)

No investigations have been conducted so far that would involve the pre-heating of a water starch suspension followed by its freezing and defrosting. Such a combination of thermal modifications is an interesting issue contributing to the state of the art.

The aim of the present study was to determine the impact of heating a water dispersion of starch to various temperatures, followed by its freezing and defrosting on the selected properties of re-prepared starch paste.

## Section snippets

## Materials

The initial study material was Superior Standard potato starch produced by PEPEES Łomża S.A. in the year 2010.

## Modification procedure

A water suspension (450 mL) was prepared from native potato starch in a measuring vessel of a Brabender viscograph (Germany), in the concentration of 4 g/100 g. The suspension was heated with the rate of 1.5 °C/min to temperatures of 59, 64, 69, 74, 79, 84, 89 or 94 °C under continuous stirring. The resultant solution was cooled to 30 °C with the rate of 1.5 °C/min, frozen for two days

## Results and discussion

Thermal modifications of starch including: roasting, freezing and defrosting, heat-moisture treatment or annealing, have been addressed in many research works. Yet, these studies did not consider the impact of the two-stage modification. In the reported experiment, a starch dispersion was first heated to various temperatures (59–94 °C) and then frozen, hence the freezing was conducted at different stages of starch pasting.

Fig. 1A presents results of paste viscosity determined at a temperature

## Conclusions

The heating of starch dispersion (in a temperature range from 59 to 74 °C), followed by its freezing and defrosting caused changes in its properties, with the tendency and extent of these changes found to be influenced by heating temperature. Depending on heating temperature, peaks could be observed in thermal characteristics of the analyzed preparations that corresponded to transitions of native starch pasting and retrograded starch solubilization. - ### [Sucrose ester alleviates the agglomeration behavior of bamboo shoot dietary fiber treated via high pressure homogenization: Influence on physicochemical, rheological, and structural properties](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S030881462300225X)



2023, Food Chemistry



Show abstract







High-pressure homogenization (HPH) is a physical modification method that can rapidly reduce the particle size of bamboo shoot dietary fiber (BSDF), but it can lead to agglomeration. Therefore, the effects of the addition of sucrose ester (SE) to alleviate the agglomeration of BSDF during HPH were investigated. Compared with BSDF without added SE, BSDF obtained the smallest particle size (276.5 nm) and highest ζ-Potential (53.6 mV) when SE was 5 g/L. Water-holding capacity, oil-holding capacity, swelling capacity, and _b\*_ increased, whereas _L\*_ and _a\*_ decreased significantly with the addition of SE. The shear stress and viscoelasticity of BSDF solution were minimized when 5 g/L SE was added. SE reduced relative crystallinity and thermal stability of BSDF. SE could effectively alleviate the aggregation of BSDF through the mechanism of electrostatic repulsion. This study highlights an innovative and promising strategy for alleviating the agglomeration behavior of BSDF during HPH treatment.

Citation Excerpt :



Additionally, different properties can be achieved by each approach. As an example, Gryszkin et al. registered increased in viscosity and in strength of starch gels after thermal modifications (heating followed by freezing and defrosting) \[64\]. Shahbazi, Majzoobi and Farahnaky observed higher surface hydrophobicity, tensile strength, and improvements on barrier properties on blends of κ-carrageenan with physically modified starch by high-pressure homogenizer than with native starch \[65\].







Show abstract







The production of sustainable food packaging from renewable sources represents a prominent alternative to the use of petrochemical-based plastics. For example, starch remains one of the more closely studied replacement options due to its broad availability, low cost and significant advances in improving properties. In this context, essential oils as additives fulfil a key role in the manufacture of renewable active packaging with superior performances. In this review, a comprehensive summary of the impact of adding essential oils to the starch-based films is provided. After a brief introduction to the fundamental concepts related to starch and essential oils, details on the most recent advances in obtaining active starch-based films are presented. Subsequently, the effects of essential oils addition on the structure-property relationships (from physicochemical to antimicrobial ones) are thoroughly addressed. Finally, applications and challenges to the widespread use of essential oils are critically discussed.

- ### [Processing of advanced green nanomaterials](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780128199886000021)



2020, Advanced Green Materials: Fabrication, Characterization and Applications of Biopolymers and Biocomposites



Show abstract







Green composites are materials having eco-friendly attributes that are technically and economically feasible while minimizing the generation of pollution. In this context, it refers to the combination of fully degradable fibers mostly cellulosic materials and natural resins to develop green composite materials. In the past decade, overdependence on petroleum products (synthetic polymers, resins, etc.) has consistently increased, and on account of this the researchers are now focusing more on green materials specially cellulosic. Green composites do not harm the environment much and could be satisfactory alternatives to petroleum-based polymers and polymer composites. The developing anxiety toward prevention of ecological destruction and the unfilled requirement for more adaptable environmental friendly materials has prompted expanding interest about polymer composites, originating from sustainable sources and biodegradable plant materials, particularly from forests. These have widened the utilization of plant fibers as reinforcements and have increased the possibility for sustainable and “biodegradable” composites, which can be called “green” composites as they satisfy the criteria of “green materials.” Thus the challenge to obtain “green” composite involves obtaining “green” polymers functioning as matrices in the production of composite materials. This chapter considers the materials and methods utilized for the fabrication and particularly the utilization of green composites in different technological fields.

- ### [Microwave radiation and protein addition modulate hydration, pasting and gel rheological characteristics of rice and potato starches](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0144861718309500)



2018, Carbohydrate Polymers







Citation Excerpt :



Consequently, MWT was always accompanied by a drop in the loss tangent, which meant a reinforcement of the elastic character of gels made from MW-treated starches or starch + protein blends compared to the untreated counterparts. Similar results have been reported for thermally-modified potato starch (Gryszkin, Zieba, Kapelko, & Buczek, 2014). Tan δ value was very low for all samples (always < 0.4), which corresponded with a well cross-linked network.







Show abstract







This study evaluated for first time the effect of Microwave (MW) radiation on systems based on potato and rice starches supplemented with 5% of calcium caseinate (CA) or soy protein isolate (SPI). The goal of this treatment was the physical modification of these starch-based systems to provide ingredients of new functionalities. The hydration and pasting properties as well as gel viscoelastic features were evaluated. Dynamic oscillatory rheological tests were used. The effect of MW treatment (MWT) depended on the starch botanical origin and was significantly affected by protein presence and type. MWT of starch + protein blends revealed the most notable changes when SPI was added. Adding it to rice starch decreased swelling power (-45%), altered viscometric profiles and reinforced gel structure with important increases in both viscoelastic moduli (+160%-G’ and +58%-G’’). In blends with potato starch, MWT increased water absorption capacity (+115%) and decreased water solubility index (-82%). MWT of protein-potato blends promoted gel stability, decreased their pasting profiles and resulted in enhanced viscoelastic moduli (+483-G’ and 243%-G’’). MWT combined with protein addition allows designing starch-based foods with tailored properties.

- ### [Determination of kinetic and thermodynamic parameters of food hydrocolloids/water interactions by means of thermal analysis and viscometry](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927775718306095)



2018, Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects







Citation Excerpt :



In the last decades, thermal properties of some hydrocolloids have been largely investigated. Particularly, thermal behaviour of starch in relation to its gelatinization and glass transition temperatures, swelling of starch granules and amylopectin and amylose content ratio were characterized in detail \[1–4\]. In spite of this fact, there is a lack of knowledge about phase transition and temperature dependency of several other food hydrocolloids.







Show abstract







The aim of this study was to determine thermal properties of pseudoplastic polysaccharides (guar gum, _κ_-carrageenan and xanthan gum) which find many applications as food hydrocolloids in food industry. There was an obvious relationship between thermal dependency of heats of fusion of hydrocolloids in powder form and activation parameters of hydrodynamic flow in solutions, respectively. Results of thermal analysis confirmed, that powder samples of hydrocolloids as typical foodstuffs of low moisture content less than 15 w% after room conditioning, exhibited varying ability to bind water as depending on their molecular structure. The peak temperature of the endothermic polysaccharide order-disorder phase transition process was found in the temperature range of 50–85 °C. It was influenced simultaneously by the applied heating rate and the samples moisture content. Studied samples moisture content was ranging between 9–40 w.% as was obtained after different conditioning. Observed reaction enthalpy ( _ΔH_) associated with phase transition and water evaporation (proved by appropriate weight loss of the samples _Δmw_) was ranging from 140 to 670 J/g. Activation energy ( _Ea_) of this process in powder samples was calculated from the kinetic parameters using three kinetic models developed by Friedman, Kissinger and model-free kinetics. The latter kinetic models were compared with the Arrhenius model, which was used to determine _Ea_ of polysaccharide solutions on reflecting sensitivity of their molecular structure to the temperature and the solvent. According to the Arrhenius model, there were obtained the highest values of _Ea_ for _κ_-carrageenan solutions, indicating the highest resistance of their molecular structure to temperature. This fact can be related to the observed the lowest value of the reaction enthalpy in the case of powder samples, suggesting that energy obtained during the order-disorder transition to change the carrageenan powder structure is limited. On the other hand, xanthan gum was the least temperature dependent sample; activation energy of xanthan solutions was only in the range of 2–6 kJ/mol. Concurrently, _ΔH_ of xanthan powder was determined as the largest of all samples under study. In general, there was found an indirect relationship between activation energy of the solutions determined by viscometry and reaction enthalpy of the powders determined by thermal analysis. Results of the Arrhenius model also indicate that the energy necessary to promote viscous flow of solutions is higher for hydrocolloids in distilled water rather than in 0.07 M KCl aqueous solutions, suggesting the suppression of the polyelectrolyte effect. In both cases, _Ea_ was substantially reduced by application of higher shear rate.

- ### [Hydrothermal modification of wheat starch. Part 2. Thermal characteristics of pasting and rheological properties of pastes](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S073352101630025X)



2016, Journal of Cereal Science







Citation Excerpt :



Investigations analogous to this study demonstrated that during re-heating the frozen and defrosted paste formed a paste with several times higher viscosity (determined from Brabender's pasting characteristics), compared to the paste made of native starch. In addition, this viscosity was positively correlated with the size of gel sacks formed (Gryszkin et al., 2014). Their structure was preserved by retrograded amylose which does not dissolve in water at the atmospheric pressure.







Show abstract







Water suspensions of starch (with the concentration of 8 g/100 g) were prepared in a measuring vessel of a Brabender viscograph and heated to temperatures of 74, 76.5, 79, 81.5, 84, 86.5, 89, 91.5 or 94 °C under continuous stirring. The resultant solution was cooled and frozen, and then defrosted. Thermal characteristics of re-pasting, rheological properties of produced pastes, starch solubility in water and swelling power were determined.



The heating and freezing of the wheat starch suspension induced changes in its properties, with tendency and extent of these changes depending on temperature of pre-heating. The thermal characteristics of the analyzed starches revealed three peaks that corresponded to transitions proceeding during solubilization of retrograded amylopectin and retrograded amylose and solubilization of amylose–lipid complexes. Retrogradation of amylose induced by starch pre-heating followed by its freezing affected also the consistency coefficient and yield stress of the pastes formed by the analyzed starches. Values of these rheological parameters were higher at higher temperatures of pre-heating, compared to the pastes prepared from native starch, and were changing accordingly to the determined second order polynomial function. Amylose retrogradation occurring during the production of starch preparations diminished their solubility in water and increased their swelling power compared to native starch.

title: Rapid Visco Analyser (RVA) as a Tool for Measuring ...
text:
Rapid Visco Analyser (RVA) as a Tool for Measuring Starch-Related
Physiochemical Properties in Cereals: a Review
Sandra Balet1,2 & Anina Guelpa1 & Glen Fox3,4 & Marena Manley1
Received: 13 December 2018 /Accepted: 26 June 2019 /Published online: 12 July 2019
# Springer Science+Business Media, LLC, part of Springer Nature 2019
Abstract
Starch, composed of amylose (AMY) and amylopectin (AP), is a common constituent of many agricultural grain crops and the
main source of energy for both humans and domesticated animals. There are several physiochemical factors that determine the
suitability of starch for a specific end use, which mainly entails the ratios of the AMYand AP, but also the granular and molecular
structure thereof. This, in turn, determines its functional properties, i.e. swelling, gelatinisation, pasting and retrogradation.
Different instruments, such as the Amylograph®, Falling Number® System, Ottawa Starch Viscometer and the
Consistometer, in addition to the more recently developed Rapid Visco Analyser (RVA) are used to study the functional
properties of starch. Due to its reliability, repeatability and versatility, the RVA is increasingly used to determine the physiochemical and, in particular, the pasting properties of cereal starches. This review gives an update on the current knowledge of
starch-related physiochemical and functional properties of a selection of cereal (i.e. wheat, barley, rice and maize) starches, and
the RVA as a measuring instrument thereof, including critical analysis and discussion.
Keywords RVA . Starch . Physiochemical properties . Gelatinisation . Pasting . Retrogradation
Introduction
Starch is a common component of cereal grains and the main
form in which carbon is stored (Carciofi et al. 2012; CuestaSeijo et al. 2013). After cellulose, starch is the most abundant
and renewable polysaccharide in cereals (Jeon et al. 2010) and
is therefore the foremost component of human food and animal feed (Copeland et al. 2009; Gilbert et al. 2013).
Molecular, crystalline and granular differences affect the
physiochemical as well as functional properties of the different cereal starches (Li et al. 2017). These differences are closely linked to the ratio of amylose (AMY) to amylopectin (AP)
present in the starch granules (Juhász and Salgó 2008). AMY
molecules are composed of mostly linear structures (glucose
monomers with α-1,4 glucosidic bonds) with a few long
branches. The AP molecules are highly branched with many
short branches, making them considerably larger in terms of
their molecular weight compared to the AMY molecules
(Beckles and Thitisaksakul 2014; Li et al. 2017). The semicrystalline growth rings in the starch granules comprised crystalline and amorphous lamellae. Regions of the formed AP
double helices fall within the crystalline lamellae while the
AP branch points lie in the alternating amorphous regions.
The AMY molecules are also present in the amorphous lamellae. This results in a highly ordered structure in the starch
granule which requires specific enzymes to initiate
degradation.
Gelatinisation, a familiar and commonly used characteristic
of starch, inflicts changes in granule swelling, birefringence
and viscosity (Zaidul et al. 2007; Juhász and Salgó 2008). It
results in irreversible changes in functional properties due to
the breakdown of the intermolecular structure of the starch
molecules (Batey 2007; Beckles and Thitisaksakul 2014).
During gelatinisation, the starch granules absorb water and
swell, melting the internal crystalline structures that lead to
the granules breaking down (Batey 2007). Pasting follows
gelatinisation and involves granular swelling and leaching of
* Marena Manley
mman@sun.ac.za
1 Department of Food Science, Stellenbosch University, Private Bag
X1, Matieland, Stellenbosch 7602, South Africa
2 Department of Agricultural Sciences, University of Juba,
P.O. Box 82, Juba, South Sudan
3 Centre for Nutrition and Food Science, Queensland Alliance for
Agriculture and Food Sciences, The University of Queensland,
Hartley Teakle Building, Brisbane, QLD 4072, Australia
4 Department of Food Science and Technology, University of
California, Davis, CA 95616, USA
Food Analytical Methods (2019) 12:2344–2360
https://doi.org/10.1007/s12161-019-01581-w
AMY molecules. During pasting, total disruption of the starch
granules takes place at a temperature higher than that of
gelatinisation. Pasting inflicts the development of a viscous
gel and can be measured by observing changes in the viscosity
based on rheological principles (Batey 2007; Zaidul et al.
2007). A further property of starch, i.e. retrogradation, involves the re-aligning and re-association of the AMY and
AP chains in the gelatinised starch, again into an ordered
crystalline structure (Batey 2007; Sandhu and Singh 2007;
Beckles and Thitisaksakul 2014). Although both AMY and
AP are capable of retrogradation, the AP component appears to be responsible for long-term changes in foods such
as bread staling.
Different instrumental methods have been employed to
study starch pasting properties, with the original method being
the Consistometer (Merill 1925). Other instruments include
the Amylograph®, Falling Number® System and Ottawa
Starch Viscometer. However, the Rapid Visco Analyser
(RVA), being more sensitive, repeatable and versatile, became
the instrument of choice in recent years (Deffenbaugh and
Walker 1989; Zhang and Hamaker 2005). The RVA mimics
the cooking process of a cereal when a flour-water suspension
is subjected to a heat-hold-cool-hold temperature cycle (Chen
et al. 2008). During the heating stage, the gelatinisation temperature of AP is reached and subsequently the paste viscosity
rises to a peak viscosity. The granules hydrate and swell causing AMY and small AP molecules to leach out (Chen et al.
2008). This is followed by the hot holding stage when a drop
in viscosity is seen. This sudden decrease in viscosity has been
associated with swelling and rigidity of starch granules as a
result of variations in the AP, AMY, lipid and protein fractions
content and/or molecular structure (Chen et al. 2008). The
viscosity rises again during the cooling phase as the soluble
AMY retrogrades, forming a gel containing gelatinised starch
granules (Chen et al. 2008).
The starch viscosity or pasting property of a given cereal
enables the improvement thereof, and aid with the selection or
screening of new breeding lines in breeding programmes
(Zhou and Mendham 2005; Cozzolino et al. 2012;
Cozzolino 2016; Batey 2007; Glennie-Holmes 1995a). The
information provided by RVA viscograms (or curves) makes
it highly suitable to study the genetic traits of cereal grains
(Chen et al. 2008). Although originally being developed to
identify pre-harvest sprouting in wheat (Ross et al. 1987),
applications have extended to pre-harvest sprouting also in
barley (Bason et al. 1993; Batey et al. 1997) and studying
the microstructure of starch pastes to elaborate on the relationship between chemical composition and pasting properties
(Singh et al. 2003b). The RVA has been shown to be useful
for a wide range of applications (Almeida-Dominguez et al.
1997a). This review aims to present the current status of
knowledge on the RVA as a tool to measure the physiochemical and functional properties of starch in a selection of cereals,
emphasising pasting properties and interpretation of results,
with critical analysis and discussion.
Starch Biology
Starch is synthesised in many organs within plants and stored
in two forms, i.e. storage and transient starch. Storage starch is
used for long-term storage in amyloplasts and is one of the
main components in cereal grains and tubers, while transient
starch is used for short-term storage in chloroplasts of vegetative organs such as leaves (Mutisya et al. 2015; Tetlow et al.
2004; Regina et al. 2010; Cuesta-Seijo et al. 2013; Sonnewald
and Kossmann 2013). Starch granules are found in different
sizes, shapes, crystalline type and composition (Table 1) depending on their botanical origin (Cuesta-Seijo et al. 2013; He
et al. 2013). Granule size ranges from 1 to 100 μm in diameter
depending on the starch type (He et al. 2012). Starch is composed of glucose polymers in the form of semi-crystalline
granules with an internal lamellar structure made up of
AMY and AP. The primary structure of these fractions is similar. Both AMY and AP are poly-glucans with the glucose
moieties linked by α-1,4-glucosidic linkages with branch
points composed of α-1,6 linkages. These two fractions, however, differ in chain length and the degree of branching, both
of which influence the physicochemical properties of the
starch (Slattery et al. 2000; Tester et al. 2004a; Hannah and
James 2008).
AMY comprises linear chains of glucose (D-glucan chain)
molecules joined by α-1,4 glucosidic linkages (Fig. 1a) with
less than 0.1% α-1,6 branch points (Kossmann and Lloyd
2000; Regina et al. 2010). The molecular weight of AMY is
ca. 105
–106 Da (Tester et al. 2004a; Copeland et al. 2009;
Thitisaksakul et al. 2012) and contains ca. 9–20 branch points
resulting in ca. 3–11 chains per molecule. Each chain contains
100–10,000 glucose residues resulting in an approximate molecular weight of between 30,000 and 110,000 Da (Tester et al.
2004b; Keeling and Myers 2010; Simsek et al. 2013).
AP also consists of linear chains of glucose (D-glucan
chain) linked by α-1,4 glucosidic bonds, but contains, in contrast to AMY, a high degree of branched points, ca. 5% α-1,6
linkages (Fig. 1b) (Kossmann and Lloyd 2000; Tester et al.
2004b; Regina et al. 2010). These linkages are organised as
such that there are distinct regions comprising a high level of
branching (amorphous region), alternating with regions devoid of branches. With a molecular weight of 107
–109 Da
(Tester et al. 2004a, 2004b), AP is thus larger and has a more
organised structure compared to AMY. AMY, however, has a
longer average chain length than AP (Tester et al. 2004a,
2004b) due to the lower frequency of branch points. AP aggregates into clusters where the chains within the cluster form
double helices resulting in a crystalline region (James et al.
2003; Sonnewald and Kossmann 2013).
Food Anal. Methods (2019) 12:2344–2360 2345
AP typically makes up the major portion of cereal grain
starch varying from ca. 60 to 85% in normal starch (Keeling
and Myers 2010) and up to 100% in waxy starch types. This
makes starch, and more specifically AP, the most abundant
single component within cereal grains which is considerably
more than proteins and other grain components considered
important in cereal grain quality.
Starch Biochemistry
ADP-glucose pyrophosphorylase (AGPase) is responsible for
the first step of starch metabolism, i.e. the production of ADPglucose. ADP-glucose is the substrate for starch synthase in
the production of AMY and AP (Smith et al. 1997; Tetlow
2011; Tetlow and Emes 2017). Starch synthase comprises of
two classes, soluble starch synthases (SSI, SSII, SSIII) and
insoluble granule-bound starch synthases (GBSSI and
GBSSII). These enzymes catalyse starch synthesis by transferring the glucosyl moiety from ADP-glucose to the nonreducing end of the α-1,4 linkage to form AP and AMY
(Ball and Morell 2003; Li et al. 2003; Morell et al. 2003;
Tetlow and Emes 2017).
Starch-branching enzymes (SBEI and SBEII) catalyse the
hydrolysis of α-1,4 glucosidic linkages within the polymer
and transfers the hydrolysed chain to form α-1,6 glucosidic
linkages (Slattery et al. 2000; Thitisaksakul et al. 2012; Tetlow
and Emes 2017). Starch-debranching enzymes (ISA1, ISA2
and PUL) determine AP structure by regulating the branching
and maintenance of AP crystallinity (Morell et al. 2003). This
process occurs in special organelles known as plastids and the
biosynthesis can occur in either amyloplasts or chloroplasts
(Smith et al. 1997; Carciofi et al. 2012). The modes of enzymatic actions that affect the rate in which these enzymes function are not yet defined (Wu et al. 2013).
Natural variation in cereal types, usually from a wild
source, can result in allelic variation in one or more of the
starchy synthesis genes (Tikapunya et al. 2017; Burton et al.
2002; Campbell et al. 2016). The most common is a mutation
or knockout of GBSS, which can result in cereal starch comprising 100% AP, called waxy-type starch (Pedersen et al.
2005). Where there is allelic variation in GBSS, a heteroFig. 1 Glucose moieties linked
by a α-1,4 to form amylose and b
by α-1,4 glucosidic linkages with
branch points composed of α-1,6
linkages to form amylopectin

2346 Food Anal. Methods (2019) 12:2344–2360
waxy is formed, which could be between 90 and 95% AP.
Variation in SSI and SSII genes can result in high AMY expression, but usually not more than 40% (Swanston et al.
2001). Variation is, however, not limited to the SS genes.
Allelic variation in either SBE or SDE will result in changes
to the structure of AP, through the degree of branching
(Campbell et al. 2016; Regina et al. 2004). The effects of these
changes on starch properties can be measured through pasting
analysis, e.g. using the RVA (Campbell et al. 2016).
The lowest level of organisation found in starch granules is
alternating crystalline (hard) and semi-crystalline (soft) shells
(Fig. 2a), only several hundred nanometers (nm) in thickness
(Gallant et al. 1997). The hard shells consist of larger blocklets
which are ca. 50–500 nm in size while, the soft shells are
smaller and range between 20 and 50 μm. At the higher level
of structure organisation, the blocklet structure shows amorphous radial channels connected by a central cavity with the
exterior of starch granule (Kossmann and Lloyd 2000; Gallant
et al. 1997). At the highest level of structure, one blocklet is
observed containing numerous amorphous crystalline lamellae besides the crystalline structure of the starch polymers
(Gallant et al. 1997) (Fig. 2b). The crystalline structure is
exclusively associated with the AP component while the
amorphous regions mainly represent AMY (Singh et al.
2006) (Fig. 2b) (Table 1).
Starch differ structurally with respect to granules, crystallinity and molecule complexes (Li et al. 2017) (Table 2). In
wheat starch, the granular structures found are either the larger
A-type or the smaller B-type granules, with similar sizerelated differences found amongst other types of cereals as
well. Further, the surface morphology of the granules also
differ and thereby contribute towards the structural differences. Also, surface pores and internal channels are present
in varying sizes, intensities and distributions. The functionality of respective starch granules implies that the larger pores
and channels allow easier access of water, chemicals and enzymes to the granule interior, and thereby enhance the starch
gelatinisation.
The chemical composition of starch granules differs due to
the varied AMY and AP contents (inherently determined by
species), which are related to the crystalline structure thereof
(Li et al. 2017). This also correlates with the size of the granules, i.e. the larger A-type granules. High-amylose maize
starch granules, when exposed to water, slowly swell due to
the large amounts of AMY packed between the small amounts
of crystalline AP (Batey 2007); thus, the level of crystallinity,
and thereby the higher amount of longer chain fractions
(AMY), plays an important role in the retrogradation as functional property of starch (Li et al. 2017).
Besides the AMY and AP ratio differences, the varied
amylose-lipid complexes and the protein and phosphorus contents also lead to differences in gelatinisation, pasting and swelling of starch, in conjunction with varying granule sizes (Li et al.
2017). Soft maize with loosely packed starch granules has
Fig. 2 a Schematic view of the
structure of a starch granule, with
alternating amorphous and
crystalline regions, constituting
the growth rings; and b represents
a blocklet structure of a starch
granule, found in the crystalline
regions and consisting of
amorphous lamellae representing
amylose, as well as the crystalline
structures, associated with
amylopectin
Food Anal. Methods (2019) 12:2344–2360 2347
reduced protein-to-starch bounds and can therefore hydrate and
swell more rapidly in the presence of heat opposed to tightly
packed granules of hard maize (Almeida-Dominguez et al.
1997b). For milled rice, the absence of surrounding protein
matrix makes hydrated and swollen starch granules more fragile, aiding disruption with a smaller ability to develop viscosity
during heating (Almeida-Dominguez et al. 1997b).
Functional Properties of Starch and its
Measurement
The application of starch and starch-based products is determined by its physicochemical or rheological properties.
The main functional properties of starch include pasting
and viscosity of the starch paste. Rheological methods play
an important role in measuring functional properties of
starch-based materials (Panozzo and McCormick 1993;
Higley et al. 2003). Pasting properties were originally measured by means of the Consistometer; however, this instrument was not economically viable and required highly
skilled operators (Merill 1925). Subsequent instruments
included the Ottawa Starch Viscometer (Deffenbaug and
Walker 1989) and the Brabender Visco-Amylograph which
became available during the 1930s. The Brabender ViscoAmylograph was modified into the Amylograph®
(Deffenbaug and Walker 1989).
More recently, the Rapid Visco Analyser (RVA) was developed by the Bread Research Institute of Australia, in collaboration with the Wheat Research Unit of CSIRO Division of
Plant Industry (Goode et al. 2005). The RVA was initially
invented as a tool to measure the extent of sprout damage, first
in wheat and later in barley (Ross et al. 1987; Wrigley 1994;
Deffenbaugh and Walker 1989). The first RVA did not include
a temperature-controlling computer; instead, the temperature
was increased manually using a heater and monitored with a
thermometer (Hazelton and Walker 1996). Recognising this
problem, the RVA was improved by incorporating computer
technology which resulted in enhanced reproducibility, versatility and more rapid measurements. In addition, development
of the paddle has ensured homogeneity of the sample and
optimal heat transfer (Hazelton and Walker 1996). The RVA
has several advantages over the Amylograph, i.e. small sample size (4 g compared to 65 g); ability to set a temperature
profile; and to report to a computer (Deffenbaugh and Walker
1989; Zhou and Mendham 2005; Crosbie and Ross 2007). In
addition, the Amylograph analysis time is approximately 2 h
due to the cooling rate of 1.5 °C/min. The RVA result obtained
was shown to be similar to that obtained with the Falling
Number apparatus, when used to determine the extent of
sprout damamge (Glennie-Holmes 1995a). The RVA has thus
been recommended for its speed as well as its strong mixing
action, compared to the Ottowa Starch Viscometer and
Amylograph (Zhou et al. 1998). Other significant differences
between the RVA and the latter two instruments include rotation speed, spindle geometries, heat transfer and sample
temperature-measuring systems (Mariotti et al. 2005).
The RVA is easy to operate and versatile in terms of test
procedures using different temperature/time profiles. The
standard profile takes 13 min to complete. The parameters
measured by the RVA are similar to the other viscometers
(Deffenbaugh and Walker 1989; Ryu et al. 1993).
In addition to the mentioned viscometers, the dynamic
Bohlin CS-50 rheometer (Goode et al. 2005) has also
been used to study the rheological properties of starch
(Singh et al. 2003a). This system has a unique starshaped paddle rotor and considers temperature/time, grit
loads, adjunct and enzyme levels (Goode et al. 2005).
Although the rheometer is very useful, the RVA is
favoured due to the following functionalities: (1) readouts
are given in standard viscosity units (mPa·s), (2) it is less
sensitive to localised disturbances, (3) it is user friendly
and (4) it is considerably cheaper to purchase (Goode
et al. 2005) (Table 3).
